name: read
signature: ssize_t read(unsigned int fd, char *buf, size_t count)
returnDescription: On success, the number of bytes read is returned (zero indicates end of file), and the file position is advanced by this number.
notes: read () attempts to read up to count bytes from file descriptor fd into the buffer starting at buf . On files that support seeking, the read operation commences at the file offset, and the file offset is incremented by the number of bytes read.

name: write
signature: ssize_t write(unsigned int fd, const char *buf, size_t count)
returnDescription: On success, the number of bytes written is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. Note that a successful write () may transfer fewer than count bytes.
notes: write () writes up to count bytes from the buffer starting at buf to the file referred to by the file descriptor fd .

name: open
description: Open and possibly create a file
signature: int open(const char *filename, int flags, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: On success, open (), openat (), and creat () return the new file descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The open () system call opens the file specified by path . If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally (if O_CREAT is specified in flags ) be created by open ().

name: close
signature: int close(unsigned int fd)
returnDescription: close () returns zero on success. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: close () closes a file descriptor, so that it no longer refers to any file and may be reused. Any record locks (see fcntl(2) ) held on the file it was associated with, and owned by the process, are removed regardless of the file descriptor that was used to obtain the lock.

name: poll
description: Wait for some event on a file descriptor
signature: int poll(struct pollfd *ufds, unsigned int nfds, int timeout_msecs)
returnDescription: On success, poll () returns a nonnegative value which is the number of elements in the pollfds whose revents fields have been set to a nonzero value (indicating an event or an error).
notes: poll () performs a similar task to select(2) : it waits for one of a set of file descriptors to become ready to perform I/O. The Linux-specific epoll(7) API performs a similar task, but offers features beyond those found in poll ().

name: lseek
signature: off_t lseek(unsigned int fd, off_t offset, unsigned int whence)
returnDescription: Upon successful completion, lseek () returns the resulting offset location as measured in bytes from the beginning of the file.
notes: lseek () repositions the file offset of the open file description associated with the file descriptor fd to the argument offset according to the directive whence as follows: SEEK_SET The file offset is set to offset bytes. SEEK_CUR The file offset is set to its current location plus offset bytes.

name: mmap
description: Map or unmap files or devices into memory
signature: void * mmap(unsigned long addr, unsigned long len, unsigned long prot, unsigned long flags, unsigned long fd, unsigned long off)
returnDescription: On success, mmap () returns a pointer to the mapped area. On error, the value MAP_FAILED (that is, (void *) -1 ) is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. On success, munmap () returns 0.
notes: mmap () creates a new mapping in the virtual address space of the calling process. The starting address for the new mapping is specified in addr . The length argument specifies the length of the mapping (which must be greater than 0).

name: mprotect
description: Set protection on a region of memory
signature: int mprotect(unsigned long start, size_t len, unsigned long prot)
returnDescription: On success, mprotect () and pkey_mprotect () return zero. On error, these system calls return -1, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mprotect () changes the access protections for the calling process's memory pages containing any part of the address range in the interval [ addr , addr + size -1]. addr must be aligned to a page boundary.

name: munmap
description: Map or unmap files or devices into memory
signature: int munmap(unsigned long addr, size_t len)
returnDescription: On success, mmap () returns a pointer to the mapped area. On error, the value MAP_FAILED (that is, (void *) -1 ) is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. On success, munmap () returns 0.
notes: mmap () creates a new mapping in the virtual address space of the calling process. The starting address for the new mapping is specified in addr . The length argument specifies the length of the mapping (which must be greater than 0).

name: brk
signature: void * brk(unsigned long brk)
returnDescription: On success, brk () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to ENOMEM . On success, sbrk () returns the previous program break.
notes: brk () and sbrk () change the location of the program break , which defines the end of the process's data segment (i.e., the program break is the first location after the end of the uninitialized data segment).

name: rt_sigaction
description: Examine and change a signal action
signature: int rt_sigaction(int sig, const struct sigaction *act, struct sigaction *oact, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: sigaction () returns 0 on success; on error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The sigaction () system call is used to change the action taken by a process on receipt of a specific signal. (See signal(7) for an overview of signals.) signum specifies the signal and can be any valid signal except SIGKILL and SIGSTOP .

name: rt_sigprocmask
signature: int rt_sigprocmask(int how, sigset_t *nset, sigset_t *oset, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: sigprocmask () returns 0 on success. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sigprocmask () is used to fetch and/or change the signal mask of the calling thread. The signal mask is the set of signals whose delivery is currently blocked for the caller (see also signal(7) for more details). The behavior of the call is dependent on the value of how , as follows.

name: rt_sigreturn
description: Return from signal handler and cleanup stack frame
signature: void rt_sigreturn(void)
returnDescription: sigreturn () never returns.
notes: If the Linux kernel determines that an unblocked signal is pending for a process, then, at the next transition back to user mode in that process (e.g.

name: ioctl
signature: int ioctl(unsigned int fd, unsigned int cmd, unsigned long arg)
returnDescription: Usually, on success zero is returned. A few ioctl () operations use the return value as an output parameter and return a nonnegative value on success.
notes: The ioctl () system call manipulates the underlying device parameters of special files. In particular, many operating characteristics of character special files (e.g., terminals) may be controlled with ioctl () operations. The argument fd must be an open file descriptor.

name: pread64
description: Read from or write to a file descriptor at a given offset
signature: ssize_t pread64(unsigned int fd, char *buf, size_t count, loff_t pos)
returnDescription: On success, pread () returns the number of bytes read (a return of zero indicates end of file) and pwrite () returns the number of bytes written.
notes: pread () reads up to count bytes from file descriptor fd at offset offset (from the start of the file) into the buffer starting at buf . The file offset is not changed. pwrite () writes up to count bytes from the buffer starting at buf to the file descriptor fd at offset offset .

name: pwrite64
description: Read from or write to a file descriptor at a given offset
signature: ssize_t pwrite64(unsigned int fd, const char *buf, size_t count, loff_t pos)
returnDescription: On success, pread () returns the number of bytes read (a return of zero indicates end of file) and pwrite () returns the number of bytes written.
notes: pread () reads up to count bytes from file descriptor fd at offset offset (from the start of the file) into the buffer starting at buf . The file offset is not changed. pwrite () writes up to count bytes from the buffer starting at buf to the file descriptor fd at offset offset .

name: readv
description: Read or write data into multiple buffers
signature: ssize_t readv(unsigned long fd, const struct iovec *vec, unsigned long vlen)
returnDescription: On success, readv (), preadv (), and preadv2 () return the number of bytes read; writev (), pwritev (), and pwritev2 () return the number of bytes written.
notes: The readv () system call reads iovcnt buffers from the file associated with the file descriptor fd into the buffers described by iov ("scatter input"). The writev () system call writes iovcnt buffers of data described by iov to the file associated with the file descriptor fd ("gather output").

name: writev
description: Read or write data into multiple buffers
signature: ssize_t writev(unsigned long fd, const struct iovec *vec, unsigned long vlen)
returnDescription: On success, readv (), preadv (), and preadv2 () return the number of bytes read; writev (), pwritev (), and pwritev2 () return the number of bytes written.
notes: The readv () system call reads iovcnt buffers from the file associated with the file descriptor fd into the buffers described by iov ("scatter input"). The writev () system call writes iovcnt buffers of data described by iov to the file associated with the file descriptor fd ("gather output").

name: access
description: Check user's permissions for a file
signature: int access(const char *filename, int mode)
returnDescription: On success (all requested permissions granted, or mode is F_OK and the file exists), zero is returned.
notes: access () checks whether the calling process can access the file path . If path is a symbolic link, it is dereferenced. The mode specifies the accessibility check(s) to be performed, and is either the value F_OK , or a mask consisting of the bitwise OR of one or more of R_OK , W_OK , and X_OK .

name: pipe
signature: int pipe(int *fildes)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and pipefd is left unchanged. On Linux (and other systems), pipe () does not modify pipefd on failure.
notes: pipe () creates a pipe, a unidirectional data channel that can be used for interprocess communication. The array pipefd is used to return two file descriptors referring to the ends of the pipe. pipefd[0] refers to the read end of the pipe. pipefd[1] refers to the write end of the pipe.

name: select
signature: int select(int n, fd_set *inp, fd_set *outp, fd_set *exp, struct old_timeval *tvp)
returnDescription: On success, select () and pselect () return the number of file descriptors contained in the three returned descriptor sets (that is, the total number of bits that are set in readfds , writefds , ex...
notes: WARNING : select () can monitor only file descriptors numbers that are less than FD_SETSIZE (1024)âan unreasonably low limit for many modern applicationsâand this limitation will not change. All modern applications should instead use poll(2) or epoll(7) , which do not suffer this limitation.

name: sched_yield
signature: int sched_yield(void)
returnDescription: On success, sched_yield () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sched_yield () causes the calling thread to relinquish the CPU. The thread is moved to the end of the queue for its static priority and a new thread gets to run.

name: mremap
signature: void * mremap(unsigned long addr, unsigned long old_len, unsigned long new_len, unsigned long flags, unsigned long new_addr)
returnDescription: On success mremap () returns a pointer to the new virtual memory area. On error, the value MAP_FAILED (that is, (void *) -1 ) is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mremap () expands (or shrinks) an existing memory mapping, potentially moving it at the same time (controlled by the flags argument and the available virtual address space).

name: msync
description: Synchronize a file with a memory map
signature: int msync(unsigned long start, size_t len, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: msync () flushes changes made to the in-core copy of a file that was mapped into memory using mmap(2) back to the filesystem. Without use of this call, there is no guarantee that changes are written back before munmap(2) is called.

name: mincore
description: Determine whether pages are resident in memory
signature: int mincore(unsigned long start, size_t len, unsigned char *vec)
returnDescription: On success, mincore () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mincore () returns a vector that indicates whether pages of the calling process's virtual memory are resident in core (RAM), and so will not cause a disk access (page fault) if referenced.

name: madvise
description: Give advice about use of memory
signature: int madvise(unsigned long start, size_t len_in, int behavior)
returnDescription: On success, madvise () returns zero. On error, it returns -1 and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The madvise () system call is used to give advice or directions to the kernel about the address range beginning at address addr and with size size . madvise () only operates on whole pages, therefore addr must be page-aligned. The value of size is rounded up to a multiple of page size.

name: shmget
description: Allocates a System V shared memory segment
signature: int shmget(key_t key, size_t size, int shmflg)
returnDescription: On success, a valid shared memory identifier is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: shmget () returns the identifier of the System V shared memory segment associated with the value of the argument key .

name: shmat
signature: void * shmat(int shmid, char *shmaddr, int shmflg)
returnDescription: On success, shmat () returns the address of the attached shared memory segment; on error, (void *) -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: shmat() shmat () attaches the System V shared memory segment identified by shmid to the address space of the calling process.

name: shmctl
signature: int shmctl(int shmid, int cmd, struct shmid_ds *buf)
returnDescription: A successful IPC_INFO or SHM_INFO operation returns the index of the highest used entry in the kernel's internal array recording information about all shared memory segments.
notes: shmctl () performs the control operation specified by op on the System V shared memory segment whose identifier is given in shmid . The buf argument is a pointer to a shmid_ds structure, defined in <sys/shm.

name: dup
signature: int dup(unsigned int fildes)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return the new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The dup () system call allocates a new file descriptor that refers to the same open file description as the descriptor oldfd . (For an explanation of open file descriptions, see open(2) .

name: dup2
signature: int dup2(unsigned int oldfd, unsigned int newfd)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return the new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The dup () system call allocates a new file descriptor that refers to the same open file description as the descriptor oldfd . (For an explanation of open file descriptions, see open(2) .

name: pause
signature: int pause(void)
returnDescription: pause () returns only when a signal was caught and the signal- catching function returned. In this case, pause () returns -1, and errno is set to EINTR .
notes: pause () causes the calling process (or thread) to sleep until a signal is delivered that either terminates the process or causes the invocation of a signal-catching function.

name: nanosleep
signature: int nanosleep(struct timespec *rqtp, struct timespec *rmtp)
returnDescription: On successfully sleeping for the requested duration, nanosleep () returns 0.
notes: nanosleep () suspends the execution of the calling thread until either at least the time specified in *duration has elapsed, or the delivery of a signal that triggers the invocation of a handler in the calling thread or that terminates the process.

name: getitimer
description: Get or set value of an interval timer
signature: int getitimer(int which, struct old_itimerval *value)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls provide access to interval timers, that is, timers that initially expire at some point in the future, and (optionally) at regular intervals after that.

name: alarm
description: Set an alarm clock for delivery of a signal
signature: int alarm(unsigned int seconds)
returnDescription: alarm () returns the number of seconds remaining until any previously scheduled alarm was due to be delivered, or zero if there was no previously scheduled alarm.
notes: alarm () arranges for a SIGALRM signal to be delivered to the calling process in seconds seconds. If seconds is zero, any pending alarm is canceled. In any event any previously set alarm () is canceled.

name: setitimer
description: Get or set value of an interval timer
signature: int setitimer(int which, struct old_itimerval *value, struct old_itimerval *ovalue)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls provide access to interval timers, that is, timers that initially expire at some point in the future, and (optionally) at regular intervals after that.

name: getpid
signature: pid_t getpid(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns a process ID. On error, -1 is returned.
notes: getpid () returns the process ID (PID) of the calling process. (This is often used by routines that generate unique temporary filenames.) getppid () returns the process ID of the parent of the calling process.

name: socket
signature: int socket(int family, int type, int protocol)
returnDescription: On success, a file descriptor for the new socket is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: socket () creates an endpoint for communication and returns a file descriptor that refers to that endpoint. The file descriptor returned by a successful call will be the lowest-numbered file descriptor not currently open for the process.

name: connect
description: Initiate a connection on a socket
signature: int connect(int fd, struct sockaddr *uservaddr, int addrlen)
returnDescription: If the connection or binding succeeds, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The connect () system call connects the socket referred to by the file descriptor sockfd to the address specified by addr . The addrlen argument specifies the size of addr . The format of the address in addr is determined by the address space of the socket sockfd ; see socket(2) for further details.

name: accept
description: Accept a connection on a socket
signature: int accept(int fd, struct sockaddr *upeer_sockaddr, int *upeer_addrlen)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return a file descriptor for the accepted socket (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and addrlen is left unchanged.
notes: The accept () system call is used with connection-based socket types ( SOCK_STREAM , SOCK_SEQPACKET ).

name: sendto
description: Send a message on a socket
signature: ssize_t sendto(int fd, void *buff, size_t len, unsigned int flags, struct sockaddr *addr, int addr_len)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return the number of bytes sent. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The system calls send (), sendto (), and sendmsg () are used to transmit a message to another socket. The send () call may be used only when the socket is in a connected state (so that the intended recipient is known). The only difference between send () and write(2) is the presence of flags .

name: recvfrom
description: Receive a message from a socket
signature: ssize_t recvfrom(int fd, void *ubuf, size_t size, unsigned int flags, struct sockaddr *addr, int *addr_len)
returnDescription: These calls return the number of bytes received, or -1 if an error occurred. In the event of an error, errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The recv (), recvfrom (), and recvmsg () calls are used to receive messages from a socket. They may be used to receive data on both connectionless and connection-oriented sockets.

name: sendmsg
description: Send a message on a socket
signature: ssize_t sendmsg(int fd, struct user_msghdr *msg, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return the number of bytes sent. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The system calls send (), sendto (), and sendmsg () are used to transmit a message to another socket. The send () call may be used only when the socket is in a connected state (so that the intended recipient is known). The only difference between send () and write(2) is the presence of flags .

name: recvmsg
description: Receive a message from a socket
signature: ssize_t recvmsg(int fd, struct user_msghdr *msg, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: These calls return the number of bytes received, or -1 if an error occurred. In the event of an error, errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The recv (), recvfrom (), and recvmsg () calls are used to receive messages from a socket. They may be used to receive data on both connectionless and connection-oriented sockets.

name: shutdown
description: Shut down part of a full-duplex connection
signature: int shutdown(int fd, int how)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The shutdown () call causes all or part of a full-duplex connection on the socket associated with sockfd to be shut down. If how is SHUT_RD , further receptions will be disallowed. If how is SHUT_WR , further transmissions will be disallowed.

name: bind
description: Bind a name to a socket
signature: int bind(int fd, struct sockaddr *umyaddr, int addrlen)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: When a socket is created with socket(2) , it exists in a name space (address family) but has no address assigned to it. bind () assigns the address specified by addr to the socket referred to by the file descriptor sockfd .

name: listen
description: Listen for connections on a socket
signature: int listen(int fd, int backlog)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: listen () marks the socket referred to by sockfd as a passive socket, that is, as a socket that will be used to accept incoming connection requests using accept(2) . The sockfd argument is a file descriptor that refers to a socket of type SOCK_STREAM or SOCK_SEQPACKET .

name: getsockname
signature: int getsockname(int fd, struct sockaddr *usockaddr, int *usockaddr_len)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getsockname () returns the current address to which the socket sockfd is bound, in the buffer pointed to by addr . The addrlen argument should be initialized to indicate the amount of space (in bytes) pointed to by addr . On return it contains the actual size of the socket address.

name: getpeername
description: Get name of connected peer socket
signature: int getpeername(int fd, struct sockaddr *usockaddr, int *usockaddr_len)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getpeername () returns the address of the peer connected to the socket sockfd , in the buffer pointed to by addr . The addrlen argument should be initialized to indicate the amount of space pointed to by addr . On return it contains the actual size of the name returned (in bytes).

name: socketpair
description: Create a pair of connected sockets
signature: int socketpair(int family, int type, int protocol, int *usockvec)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and sv is left unchanged On Linux (and other systems), socketpair () does not modify sv on failure.
notes: The socketpair () call creates an unnamed pair of connected sockets in the specified domain , of the specified type , and using the optionally specified protocol . For further details of these arguments, see socket(2) .

name: setsockopt
description: Get and set options on sockets
signature: int setsockopt(int fd, int level, int optname, char *optval, int optlen)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned for the standard options. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getsockopt () and setsockopt () manipulate options for the socket referred to by the file descriptor sockfd . Options may exist at multiple protocol levels; they are always present at the uppermost socket level.

name: getsockopt
description: Get and set options on sockets
signature: int getsockopt(int fd, int level, int optname, char *optval, int *optlen)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned for the standard options. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getsockopt () and setsockopt () manipulate options for the socket referred to by the file descriptor sockfd . Options may exist at multiple protocol levels; they are always present at the uppermost socket level.

name: clone
signature: pid_t clone(unsigned long clone_flags, unsigned long newsp, int *parent_tidptr, int *child_tidptr, unsigned long tls)
returnDescription: On success, the thread ID of the child process is returned in the caller's thread of execution.
notes: These system calls create a new ("child") process, in a manner similar to fork(2) . By contrast with fork(2) , these system calls provide more precise control over what pieces of execution context are shared between the calling process and the child process.

name: fork
signature: pid_t fork(void)
returnDescription: On success, the PID of the child process is returned in the parent, and 0 is returned in the child.
notes: fork () creates a new process by duplicating the calling process. The new process is referred to as the child process. The calling process is referred to as the parent process. The child process and the parent process run in separate memory spaces.

name: vfork
description: Create a child process and block parent
signature: pid_t vfork(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns a process ID. On error, -1 is returned.
notes: Standard description (From POSIX.1) The vfork () function has the same effect as fork(2) , except that the behavior is undefined if the process created by vfork () either modifies any data other than a variable of type pid_t used to store the return value from vfork (), or returns from the functi...

name: execve
signature: int execve(const char *filename, const char *const *argv, const char *const *envp)
returnDescription: On success, execve () does not return, on error -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: execve () executes the program referred to by path . This causes the program that is currently being run by the calling process to be replaced with a new program, with newly initialized stack, heap, and (initialized and uninitialized) data segments.

name: exit
signature: void exit(int error_code)
returnDescription: These functions do not return.
notes: _exit () terminates the calling process "immediately". Any open file descriptors belonging to the process are closed. Any children of the process are inherited by init(1) (or by the nearest "subreaper" process as defined through the use of the prctl(2) PR_SET_CHILD_SUBREAPER operation).

name: wait4
description: Wait for process to change state, BSD style
signature: pid_t wait4(pid_t upid, int *stat_addr, int options, struct rusage *ru)
returnDescription: As for waitpid(2) .
notes: These functions are nonstandard; in new programs, the use of waitpid(2) or waitid(2) is preferable. The wait3 () and wait4 () system calls are similar to waitpid(2) , but additionally return resource usage information about the child in the structure pointed to by rusage .

name: kill
signature: int kill(pid_t pid, int sig)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. If signals were sent to a process group, success means that at least one signal was delivered. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The kill () system call can be used to send any signal to any process group or process. If pid is positive, then signal sig is sent to the process with the ID specified by pid . If pid equals 0, then sig is sent to every process in the process group of the calling process.

name: semget
description: Get a System V semaphore set identifier
signature: int semget(key_t key, int nsems, int semflg)
returnDescription: On success, semget () returns the semaphore set identifier (a nonnegative integer). On failure, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The semget () system call returns the System V semaphore set identifier associated with the argument key . It may be used either to obtain the identifier of a previously created semaphore set (when semflg is zero and key does not have the value IPC_PRIVATE ), or to create a new set.

name: semop
signature: int semop(int semid, struct sembuf *tsops, unsigned nsops)
returnDescription: On success, semop () and semtimedop () return 0. On failure, they return -1, and set errno to indicate the error.
notes: Each semaphore in a System V semaphore set has the following associated values: unsigned short semval; /* semaphore value */ unsigned short semzcnt; /* # waiting for zero */ unsigned short semncnt; /* # waiting for increase */ pid_t sempid; /* PID of process that last modified the semaphore value...

name: semctl
signature: int semctl(int semid, int semnum, int cmd, unsigned long arg)
returnDescription: On success, semctl () returns a nonnegative value depending on op as follows: GETNCNT the value of semncnt . GETPID the value of sempid . GETVAL the value of semval . GETZCNT the value of semzcnt .
notes: semctl () performs the control operation specified by op on the System V semaphore set identified by semid , or on the semnum -th semaphore of that set. (The semaphores in a set are numbered starting at 0.) This function has three or four arguments, depending on op .

name: shmdt
signature: int shmdt(char *shmaddr)
returnDescription: On success, shmat () returns the address of the attached shared memory segment; on error, (void *) -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: shmat() shmat () attaches the System V shared memory segment identified by shmid to the address space of the calling process.

name: msgget
description: Get a System V message queue identifier
signature: int msgget(key_t key, int msgflg)
returnDescription: On success, msgget () returns the message queue identifier (a nonnegative integer). On failure, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The msgget () system call returns the System V message queue identifier associated with the value of the key argument. It may be used either to obtain the identifier of a previously created message queue (when msgflg is zero and key does not have the value IPC_PRIVATE ), or to create a new set.

name: msgsnd
signature: int msgsnd(int msqid, struct msgbuf *msgp, size_t msgsz, int msgflg)
returnDescription: On success, msgsnd () returns 0 and msgrcv () returns the number of bytes actually copied into the mtext array. On failure, both functions return -1, and set errno to indicate the error.
notes: The msgsnd () and msgrcv () system calls are used to send messages to, and receive messages from, a System V message queue. The calling process must have write permission on the message queue in order to send a message, and read permission to receive a message.

name: msgrcv
signature: int msgrcv(int msqid, struct msgbuf *msgp, size_t msgsz, long msgtyp, int msgflg)
returnDescription: On success, msgsnd () returns 0 and msgrcv () returns the number of bytes actually copied into the mtext array. On failure, both functions return -1, and set errno to indicate the error.
notes: The msgsnd () and msgrcv () system calls are used to send messages to, and receive messages from, a System V message queue. The calling process must have write permission on the message queue in order to send a message, and read permission to receive a message.

name: msgctl
signature: int msgctl(int msqid, int cmd, struct msqid_ds *buf)
returnDescription: On success, IPC_STAT , IPC_SET , and IPC_RMID return 0.
notes: msgctl () performs the control operation specified by op on the System V message queue with identifier msqid . The msqid_ds data structure is defined in <sys/msg.

name: fcntl
signature: int fcntl(unsigned int fd, unsigned int cmd, unsigned long arg)
returnDescription: For a successful call, the return value depends on the operation. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: fcntl () performs one of the operations described below on the open file descriptor fd . The operation is determined by op . Certain of the operations below are supported only since a particular Linux kernel version.

name: flock
description: Apply or remove an advisory lock on an open file
signature: int flock(unsigned int fd, unsigned int cmd)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Apply or remove an advisory lock on the open file specified by fd . The argument op is one of the following: LOCK_SH Place a shared lock. More than one process may hold a shared lock for a given file at a given time. LOCK_EX Place an exclusive lock.

name: fsync
description: Synchronize a file's in-core state with storage device
signature: int fsync(unsigned int fd)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: fsync () transfers ("flushes") all modified in-core data of (i.e., modified buffer cache pages for) the file referred to by the file descriptor fd to the disk device (or other permanent storage device) so that all changed information can be retrieved even if the system crashes or is rebooted.

name: fdatasync
description: Synchronize a file's in-core state with storage device
signature: int fdatasync(unsigned int fd)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: fsync () transfers ("flushes") all modified in-core data of (i.e., modified buffer cache pages for) the file referred to by the file descriptor fd to the disk device (or other permanent storage device) so that all changed information can be retrieved even if the system crashes or is rebooted.

name: truncate
description: Truncate a file to a specified length
signature: int truncate(const char *path, long length)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The truncate () and ftruncate () functions cause the regular file named by path or referenced by fd to be truncated to a size of precisely length bytes. If the file previously was larger than this size, the extra data is lost.

name: ftruncate
description: Truncate a file to a specified length
signature: int ftruncate(unsigned int fd, off_t length)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The truncate () and ftruncate () functions cause the regular file named by path or referenced by fd to be truncated to a size of precisely length bytes. If the file previously was larger than this size, the extra data is lost.

name: getdents
signature: int getdents(unsigned int fd, struct linux_dirent *dirent, unsigned int count)
returnDescription: On success, the number of bytes read is returned. On end of directory, 0 is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These are not the interfaces you are interested in. Look at readdir(3) for the POSIX-conforming C library interface. This page documents the bare kernel system call interfaces.

name: getcwd
signature: int getcwd(char *buf, unsigned long size)
returnDescription: On success, these functions return a pointer to a string containing the pathname of the current working directory. In the case of getcwd () and getwd () this is the same value as buf .
notes: These functions return a null-terminated string containing an absolute pathname that is the current working directory of the calling process. The pathname is returned as the function result and via the argument buf , if present.

name: chdir
signature: int chdir(const char *filename)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: chdir () changes the current working directory of the calling process to the directory specified in path . fchdir () is identical to chdir (); the only difference is that the directory is given as an open file descriptor.

name: fchdir
signature: int fchdir(unsigned int fd)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: chdir () changes the current working directory of the calling process to the directory specified in path . fchdir () is identical to chdir (); the only difference is that the directory is given as an open file descriptor.

name: rename
description: Change the name or location of a file
signature: int rename(const char *oldname, const char *newname)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: rename () renames a file, moving it between directories if required. Any other hard links to the file (as created using link(2) ) are unaffected. Open file descriptors for oldpath are also unaffected. Various restrictions determine whether or not the rename operation succeeds: see ERRORS below.

name: mkdir
signature: int mkdir(const char *pathname, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: mkdir () and mkdirat () return zero on success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mkdir () attempts to create a directory named path . The argument mode specifies the mode for the new directory (see inode(7) ). It is modified by the process's umask in the usual way: in the absence of a default ACL, the mode of the created directory is ( mode & ~ umask & 0777).

name: rmdir
signature: int rmdir(const char *pathname)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: rmdir () deletes a directory, which must be empty.

name: creat
description: Open and possibly create a file
signature: int creat(const char *pathname, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: On success, open (), openat (), and creat () return the new file descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The open () system call opens the file specified by path . If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally (if O_CREAT is specified in flags ) be created by open ().

name: link
description: Make a new name for a file
signature: int link(const char *oldname, const char *newname)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: link () creates a new link (also known as a hard link) to an existing file. If newpath exists, it will not be overwritten.

name: unlink
description: Delete a name and possibly the file it refers to
signature: int unlink(const char *pathname)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: unlink () deletes a name from the filesystem. If that name was the last link to a file and no processes have the file open, the file is deleted and the space it was using is made available for reuse.

name: symlink
description: Make a new name for a file
signature: int symlink(const char *oldname, const char *newname)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: symlink () creates a symbolic link named linkpath which contains the string target . Symbolic links are interpreted at run time as if the contents of the link had been substituted into the path being followed to find a file or directory. Symbolic links may contain ..

name: readlink
description: Read value of a symbolic link
signature: ssize_t readlink(const char *path, char *buf, int bufsiz)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return the number of bytes placed in buf . (If the returned value equals bufsiz , then truncation may have occurred.
notes: readlink () places the contents of the symbolic link path in the buffer buf , which has size bufsiz . readlink () does not append a terminating null byte to buf . It will (silently) truncate the contents (to a length of bufsiz characters), in case the buffer is too small to hold all of the contents.

name: chmod
signature: int chmod(const char *filename, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The chmod () and fchmod () system calls change a file's mode bits. (The file mode consists of the file permission bits plus the set- user-ID, set-group-ID, and sticky bits.

name: fchmod
signature: int fchmod(unsigned int fd, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The chmod () and fchmod () system calls change a file's mode bits. (The file mode consists of the file permission bits plus the set- user-ID, set-group-ID, and sticky bits.

name: chown
signature: int chown(const char *filename, uid_t user, gid_t group)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls change the owner and group of a file. The chown (), fchown (), and lchown () system calls differ only in how the file is specified: â¢ chown () changes the ownership of the file specified by path , which is dereferenced if it is a symbolic link.

name: fchown
signature: int fchown(unsigned int fd, uid_t user, gid_t group)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls change the owner and group of a file. The chown (), fchown (), and lchown () system calls differ only in how the file is specified: â¢ chown () changes the ownership of the file specified by path , which is dereferenced if it is a symbolic link.

name: lchown
signature: int lchown(const char *filename, uid_t user, gid_t group)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls change the owner and group of a file. The chown (), fchown (), and lchown () system calls differ only in how the file is specified: â¢ chown () changes the ownership of the file specified by path , which is dereferenced if it is a symbolic link.

name: umask
signature: mode_t umask(int mask)
returnDescription: This system call always succeeds and the previous value of the mask is returned.
notes: umask () sets the calling process's file mode creation mask (umask) to mask & 0777 (i.e., only the file permission bits of mask are used), and returns the previous value of the mask.

name: gettimeofday
signature: int gettimeofday(struct old_timeval *tv, struct timezone *tz)
returnDescription: gettimeofday () and settimeofday () return 0 for success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The functions gettimeofday () and settimeofday () can get and set the time as well as a timezone. The tv argument is a struct timeval (as specified in <sys/time.

name: getrlimit
signature: int getrlimit(unsigned int resource, struct rlimit *rlim)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The getrlimit () and setrlimit () system calls get and set resource limits. Each resource has an associated soft and hard limit, as defined by the rlimit structure. The soft limit is the value that the kernel enforces for the corresponding resource.

name: getrusage
signature: int getrusage(int who, struct rusage *ru)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getrusage () returns resource usage measures for who , which can be one of the following: RUSAGE_SELF Return resource usage statistics for the calling process, which is the sum of resources used by all threads in the process.

name: sysinfo
signature: int sysinfo(struct sysinfo *info)
returnDescription: On success, sysinfo () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sysinfo () returns certain statistics on memory and swap usage, as well as the load average. Until Linux 2.3.

name: times
signature: clock_t times(struct tms *tbuf)
returnDescription: times () returns the number of clock ticks that have elapsed since an arbitrary point in the past. The return value may overflow the possible range of type clock_t .
notes: times () stores the current process times in the struct tms that buf points to. The struct tms is as defined in <sys/times.

name: ptrace
signature: int ptrace(long request, long pid, unsigned long addr, unsigned long data)
returnDescription: On success, the PTRACE_PEEK* operations return the requested data (but see NOTES), the PTRACE_SECCOMP_GET_FILTER operation returns the number of instructions in the BPF program, the PTRACE_GET_SYSC...
notes: The ptrace () system call provides a means by which one process (the "tracer") may observe and control the execution of another process (the "tracee"), and examine and change the tracee's memory and registers. It is primarily used to implement breakpoint debugging and system call tracing.

name: getuid
signature: uid_t getuid(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.
notes: getuid () returns the real user ID of the calling process. geteuid () returns the effective user ID of the calling process.

name: syslog
description: Read and/or clear kernel message ring buffer; set console_loglevel
signature: int syslog(int type, char *buf, int len)
returnDescription: For type equal to 2, 3, or 4, a successful call to syslog () returns the number of bytes read.
notes: Note : Probably, you are looking for the C library function syslog (), which talks to syslogd (8); see syslog(3) for details.

name: getgid
signature: gid_t getgid(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.
notes: getgid () returns the real group ID of the calling process. getegid () returns the effective group ID of the calling process.

name: setuid
signature: int setuid(uid_t uid)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: setuid () sets the effective user ID of the calling process. If the calling process is privileged (more precisely: if the process has the CAP_SETUID capability in its user namespace), the real UID and saved set-user-ID are also set.

name: setgid
signature: int setgid(gid_t gid)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: setgid () sets the effective group ID of the calling process. If the calling process is privileged (more precisely: has the CAP_SETGID capability in its user namespace), the real GID and saved set-group-ID are also set.

name: geteuid
signature: uid_t geteuid(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.
notes: getuid () returns the real user ID of the calling process. geteuid () returns the effective user ID of the calling process.

name: getegid
signature: gid_t getegid(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.
notes: getgid () returns the real group ID of the calling process. getegid () returns the effective group ID of the calling process.

name: setpgid
signature: int setpgid(pid_t pid, pid_t pgid)
returnDescription: On success, setpgid () and setpgrp () return zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The POSIX.1 getpgrp () always returns the PGID of the caller.
notes: All of these interfaces are available on Linux, and are used for getting and setting the process group ID (PGID) of a process. The preferred, POSIX.1-specified ways of doing this are: getpgrp (void), for retrieving the calling process's PGID; and setpgid (), for setting a process's PGID.

name: getppid
signature: pid_t getppid(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns a process ID. On error, -1 is returned.
notes: getpid () returns the process ID (PID) of the calling process. (This is often used by routines that generate unique temporary filenames.) getppid () returns the process ID of the parent of the calling process.

name: getpgrp
signature: pid_t getpgrp(void)
returnDescription: On success, setpgid () and setpgrp () return zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The POSIX.1 getpgrp () always returns the PGID of the caller.
notes: All of these interfaces are available on Linux, and are used for getting and setting the process group ID (PGID) of a process. The preferred, POSIX.1-specified ways of doing this are: getpgrp (void), for retrieving the calling process's PGID; and setpgid (), for setting a process's PGID.

name: setsid
description: Creates a session and sets the process group ID
signature: int setsid(void)
returnDescription: On success, the (new) session ID of the calling process is returned. On error, (pid_t) -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: setsid () creates a new session if the calling process is not a process group leader. The calling process is the leader of the new session (i.e., its session ID is made the same as its process ID). The calling process also becomes the process group leader of a new process group in the session (i.e.

name: setreuid
description: Set real and/or effective user or group ID
signature: int setreuid(uid_t ruid, uid_t euid)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: setreuid () sets real and effective user IDs of the calling process. Supplying a value of -1 for either the real or effective user ID forces the system to leave that ID unchanged.

name: setregid
description: Set real and/or effective user or group ID
signature: int setregid(gid_t rgid, gid_t egid)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: setreuid () sets real and effective user IDs of the calling process. Supplying a value of -1 for either the real or effective user ID forces the system to leave that ID unchanged.

name: getgroups
description: Get/set list of supplementary group IDs
signature: int getgroups(int gidsetsize, gid_t *grouplist)
returnDescription: On success, getgroups () returns the number of supplementary group IDs. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. On success, setgroups () returns 0.
notes: getgroups () returns the supplementary group IDs of the calling process in list . The argument size should be set to the maximum number of items that can be stored in the buffer pointed to by list . If the calling process is a member of more than size supplementary groups, then an error results.

name: setgroups
description: Get/set list of supplementary group IDs
signature: int setgroups(int gidsetsize, gid_t *grouplist)
returnDescription: On success, getgroups () returns the number of supplementary group IDs. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. On success, setgroups () returns 0.
notes: getgroups () returns the supplementary group IDs of the calling process in list . The argument size should be set to the maximum number of items that can be stored in the buffer pointed to by list . If the calling process is a member of more than size supplementary groups, then an error results.

name: setresuid
description: Set real, effective, and saved user or group ID
signature: int setresuid(uid_t ruid, uid_t euid, uid_t suid)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: setresuid () sets the real user ID, the effective user ID, and the saved set-user-ID of the calling process. An unprivileged process may change its real UID, effective UID, and saved set-user-ID, each to one of: the current real UID, the current effective UID, or the current saved set-user-ID.

name: getresuid
description: Get real, effective, and saved user/group IDs
signature: int getresuid(uid_t *ruidp, uid_t *euidp, uid_t *suidp)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getresuid () returns the real UID, the effective UID, and the saved set-user-ID of the calling process, in the arguments ruid , euid , and suid , respectively. getresgid () performs the analogous task for the process's group IDs.

name: setresgid
description: Set real, effective, and saved user or group ID
signature: int setresgid(gid_t rgid, gid_t egid, gid_t sgid)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: setresuid () sets the real user ID, the effective user ID, and the saved set-user-ID of the calling process. An unprivileged process may change its real UID, effective UID, and saved set-user-ID, each to one of: the current real UID, the current effective UID, or the current saved set-user-ID.

name: getresgid
description: Get real, effective, and saved user/group IDs
signature: int getresgid(gid_t *rgidp, gid_t *egidp, gid_t *sgidp)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getresuid () returns the real UID, the effective UID, and the saved set-user-ID of the calling process, in the arguments ruid , euid , and suid , respectively. getresgid () performs the analogous task for the process's group IDs.

name: getpgid
signature: pid_t getpgid(pid_t pid)
returnDescription: On success, setpgid () and setpgrp () return zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The POSIX.1 getpgrp () always returns the PGID of the caller.
notes: All of these interfaces are available on Linux, and are used for getting and setting the process group ID (PGID) of a process. The preferred, POSIX.1-specified ways of doing this are: getpgrp (void), for retrieving the calling process's PGID; and setpgid (), for setting a process's PGID.

name: setfsuid
description: Set user identity used for filesystem checks
signature: int setfsuid(uid_t uid)
returnDescription: On both success and failure, this call returns the previous filesystem user ID of the caller.
notes: On Linux, a process has both a filesystem user ID and an effective user ID. The (Linux-specific) filesystem user ID is used for permissions checking when accessing filesystem objects, while the effective user ID is used for various other kinds of permissions checks (see credentials(7) ).

name: setfsgid
description: Set group identity used for filesystem checks
signature: int setfsgid(gid_t gid)
returnDescription: On both success and failure, this call returns the previous filesystem group ID of the caller.
notes: On Linux, a process has both a filesystem group ID and an effective group ID. The (Linux-specific) filesystem group ID is used for permissions checking when accessing filesystem objects, while the effective group ID is used for some other kinds of permissions checks (see credentials(7) ).

name: getsid
signature: pid_t getsid(pid_t pid)
returnDescription: On success, a session ID is returned. On error, (pid_t) -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: getsid () returns the session ID of the process with process ID pid . If pid is 0, getsid () returns the session ID of the calling process.

name: capget
signature: int capget(cap_user_header_t header, cap_user_data_t dataptr)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These two system calls are the raw kernel interface for getting and setting thread capabilities. Not only are these system calls specific to Linux, but the kernel API is likely to change and use of these system calls (in particular the format of the cap_user_*_t types) is subject to extension wit...

name: capset
signature: int capset(cap_user_header_t header, const cap_user_data_t data)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These two system calls are the raw kernel interface for getting and setting thread capabilities. Not only are these system calls specific to Linux, but the kernel API is likely to change and use of these system calls (in particular the format of the cap_user_*_t types) is subject to extension wit...

name: rt_sigpending
signature: int rt_sigpending(sigset_t *uset, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: sigpending () returns 0 on success. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sigpending () returns the set of signals that are pending for delivery to the calling thread (i.e., the signals which have been raised while blocked). The mask of pending signals is returned in set .

name: rt_sigtimedwait
signature: int rt_sigtimedwait(const sigset_t *uthese, siginfo_t *uinfo, const struct timespec *uts, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: On success, both sigwaitinfo () and sigtimedwait () return a signal number (i.e., a value greater than zero). On failure both calls return -1, with errno set to indicate the error.
notes: sigwaitinfo () suspends execution of the calling thread until one of the signals in set is pending (If one of the signals in set is already pending for the calling thread, sigwaitinfo () will return immediately.

name: rt_sigqueueinfo
signature: int rt_sigqueueinfo(pid_t pid, int sig, siginfo_t *uinfo)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, they return -1 and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The rt_sigqueueinfo () and rt_tgsigqueueinfo () system calls are the low-level interfaces used to send a signal plus data to a process or thread. The receiver of the signal can obtain the accompanying data by establishing a signal handler with the sigaction(2) SA_SIGINFO flag.

name: rt_sigsuspend
signature: int rt_sigsuspend(sigset_t *unewset, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: sigsuspend () always returns -1, with errno set to indicate the error (normally, EINTR ).
notes: sigsuspend () temporarily replaces the signal mask of the calling thread with the mask given by mask and then suspends the thread until delivery of a signal whose action is to invoke a signal handler or to terminate a process. If the signal terminates the process, then sigsuspend () does not return.

name: sigaltstack
description: Set and/or get signal stack context
signature: int sigaltstack(const stack_t *uss, stack_t *uoss)
returnDescription: sigaltstack () returns 0 on success, or -1 on failure with errno set to indicate the error.
notes: sigaltstack () allows a thread to define a new alternate signal stack and/or retrieve the state of an existing alternate signal stack. An alternate signal stack is used during the execution of a signal handler if the establishment of that handler (see sigaction(2) ) requested it.

name: utime
description: Change file last access and modification times
signature: int utime(char *filename, struct utimbuf *times)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Note: modern applications may prefer to use the interfaces described in utimensat(2) . The utime () system call changes the access and modification times of the inode specified by path to the actime and modtime fields of times respectively.

name: mknod
description: Create a special or ordinary file
signature: int mknod(const char *filename, umode_t mode, unsigned dev)
returnDescription: mknod () and mknodat () return zero on success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The system call mknod () creates a filesystem node (file, device special file, or named pipe) named path , with attributes specified by mode and dev . The mode argument specifies both the file mode to use and the type of node to be created.

name: personality
signature: int personality(unsigned int personality)
returnDescription: On success, the previous persona is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Linux supports different execution domains, or personalities, for each process. Among other things, execution domains tell Linux how to map signal numbers into signal actions.

name: ustat
signature: int ustat(unsigned dev, struct ustat *ubuf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned and the ustat structure pointed to by ubuf will be filled in. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: ustat () returns information about a mounted filesystem. dev is a device number identifying a device containing a mounted filesystem.

name: statfs
signature: int statfs(const char *pathname, struct statfs *buf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The statfs () system call returns information about a mounted filesystem. path is the pathname of any file within the mounted filesystem.

name: fstatfs
signature: int fstatfs(unsigned int fd, struct statfs *buf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The statfs () system call returns information about a mounted filesystem. path is the pathname of any file within the mounted filesystem.

name: getpriority
signature: int getpriority(int which, int who)
returnDescription: On success, getpriority () returns the calling thread's nice value, which may be a negative number. On error, it returns -1 and sets errno to indicate the error.
notes: The scheduling priority of the process, process group, or user, as indicated by which and who is obtained with the getpriority () call and set with the setpriority () call.

name: setpriority
signature: int setpriority(int which, int who, int niceval)
returnDescription: On success, getpriority () returns the calling thread's nice value, which may be a negative number. On error, it returns -1 and sets errno to indicate the error.
notes: The scheduling priority of the process, process group, or user, as indicated by which and who is obtained with the getpriority () call and set with the setpriority () call.

name: sched_setparam
signature: int sched_setparam(pid_t pid, struct sched_param *param)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setparam () and sched_getparam () return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sched_setparam () sets the scheduling parameters associated with the scheduling policy for the thread whose thread ID is specified in pid . If pid is zero, then the parameters of the calling thread are set.

name: sched_getparam
signature: int sched_getparam(pid_t pid, struct sched_param *param)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setparam () and sched_getparam () return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sched_setparam () sets the scheduling parameters associated with the scheduling policy for the thread whose thread ID is specified in pid . If pid is zero, then the parameters of the calling thread are set.

name: sched_setscheduler
signature: int sched_setscheduler(pid_t pid, int policy, struct sched_param *param)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setscheduler () returns zero. On success, sched_getscheduler () returns the policy for the thread (a nonnegative integer).
notes: The sched_setscheduler () system call sets both the scheduling policy and parameters for the thread whose ID is specified in pid . If pid equals zero, the scheduling policy and parameters of the calling thread will be set.

name: sched_getscheduler
signature: int sched_getscheduler(pid_t pid)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setscheduler () returns zero. On success, sched_getscheduler () returns the policy for the thread (a nonnegative integer).
notes: The sched_setscheduler () system call sets both the scheduling policy and parameters for the thread whose ID is specified in pid . If pid equals zero, the scheduling policy and parameters of the calling thread will be set.

name: sched_get_priority_max
signature: int sched_get_priority_max(int policy)
returnDescription: On success, sched_get_priority_max () and sched_get_priority_min () return the maximum/minimum priority value for the named scheduling policy.
notes: sched_get_priority_max () returns the maximum priority value that can be used with the scheduling algorithm identified by policy . sched_get_priority_min () returns the minimum priority value that can be used with the scheduling algorithm identified by policy .

name: sched_get_priority_min
signature: int sched_get_priority_min(int policy)
returnDescription: On success, sched_get_priority_max () and sched_get_priority_min () return the maximum/minimum priority value for the named scheduling policy.
notes: sched_get_priority_max () returns the maximum priority value that can be used with the scheduling algorithm identified by policy . sched_get_priority_min () returns the minimum priority value that can be used with the scheduling algorithm identified by policy .

name: sched_rr_get_interval
description: Get the SCHED_RR interval for the named process
signature: int sched_rr_get_interval(pid_t pid, struct timespec *interval)
returnDescription: On success, sched_rr_get_interval () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sched_rr_get_interval () writes into the timespec (3) structure pointed to by tp the round-robin time quantum for the process identified by pid . The specified process should be running under the SCHED_RR scheduling policy.

name: mlock
signature: int mlock(unsigned long start, size_t len)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and no changes are made to any locks in the address space of the process.
notes: mlock (), mlock2 (), and mlockall () lock part or all of the calling process's virtual address space into RAM, preventing that memory from being paged to the swap area.

name: munlock
signature: int munlock(unsigned long start, size_t len)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and no changes are made to any locks in the address space of the process.
notes: mlock (), mlock2 (), and mlockall () lock part or all of the calling process's virtual address space into RAM, preventing that memory from being paged to the swap area.

name: mlockall
signature: int mlockall(int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and no changes are made to any locks in the address space of the process.
notes: mlock (), mlock2 (), and mlockall () lock part or all of the calling process's virtual address space into RAM, preventing that memory from being paged to the swap area.

name: munlockall
signature: int munlockall(void)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and no changes are made to any locks in the address space of the process.
notes: mlock (), mlock2 (), and mlockall () lock part or all of the calling process's virtual address space into RAM, preventing that memory from being paged to the swap area.

name: vhangup
signature: int vhangup(void)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: vhangup () simulates a hangup on the current terminal. This call arranges for other users to have a âcleanâ terminal at login time.

name: pivot_root
signature: int pivot_root(const char *new_root, const char *put_old)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: pivot_root () changes the root mount in the mount namespace of the calling process. More precisely, it moves the root mount to the directory put_old and makes new_root the new root mount.

name: prctl
description: Operations on a process or thread
signature: int prctl(int option, unsigned long arg2, unsigned long arg3, unsigned long arg4, unsigned long arg5)
returnDescription: On success, a nonnegative value is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: prctl () manipulates various aspects of the behavior of the calling thread or process. prctl () is called with a first argument describing what to do, and further arguments with a significance depending on the first one.

name: arch_prctl
signature: int arch_prctl(int option, unsigned long arg2)
returnDescription: On success, arch_prctl () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: arch_prctl () sets architecture-specific process or thread state. op selects an operation and passes argument addr to it; addr is interpreted as either an unsigned long for the "set" operations, or as an unsigned long * , for the "get" operations.

name: adjtimex
signature: int adjtimex(struct timex *txc_p)
returnDescription: On success, adjtimex () and ntp_adjtime () return the clock state; that is, one of the following values: TIME_OK Clock synchronized, no leap second adjustment pending.
notes: Linux uses David L. Mills' clock adjustment algorithm (see RFC 5905). The system call adjtimex () reads and optionally sets adjustment parameters for this algorithm.

name: setrlimit
signature: int setrlimit(unsigned int resource, struct rlimit *rlim)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The getrlimit () and setrlimit () system calls get and set resource limits. Each resource has an associated soft and hard limit, as defined by the rlimit structure. The soft limit is the value that the kernel enforces for the corresponding resource.

name: chroot
signature: int chroot(const char *filename)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: chroot () changes the root directory of the calling process to that specified in path . This directory will be used for pathnames beginning with / . The root directory is inherited by all children of the calling process.

name: sync
signature: int sync(void)
returnDescription: syncfs () returns 0 on success; on error, it returns -1 and sets errno to indicate the error.
notes: sync () causes all pending modifications to filesystem metadata and cached file data to be written to the underlying filesystems. syncfs () is like sync (), but synchronizes just the filesystem containing file referred to by the open file descriptor fd .

name: acct
description: Switch process accounting on or off
signature: int acct(const char *name)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The acct () system call enables or disables process accounting. If called with the pathname of an existing file as its argument, accounting is turned on, and records for each terminating process are appended to the file as it terminates. An argument of NULL causes accounting to be turned off.

name: settimeofday
signature: int settimeofday(struct old_timeval *tv, struct timezone *tz)
returnDescription: gettimeofday () and settimeofday () return 0 for success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The functions gettimeofday () and settimeofday () can get and set the time as well as a timezone. The tv argument is a struct timeval (as specified in <sys/time.

name: mount
signature: int mount(char *dev_name, char *dir_name, char *type, unsigned long flags, void *data)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mount () attaches the filesystem specified by source (which is often a pathname referring to a device, but can also be the pathname of a directory or file, or a dummy string) to the location (a directory or file) specified by the pathname in target .

name: umount
signature: int umount(char *name, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: umount () and umount2 () remove the attachment of the (topmost) filesystem mounted on target . Appropriate privilege (Linux: the CAP_SYS_ADMIN capability) is required to unmount filesystems. Linux 2.1.

name: swapon
signature: int swapon(const char *specialfile, int swap_flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: swapon () sets the swap area to the file or block device specified by path . swapoff () stops swapping to the file or block device specified by path . If the SWAP_FLAG_PREFER flag is specified in the swapon () swapflags argument, the new swap area will have a higher priority than default.

name: swapoff
signature: int swapoff(const char *specialfile)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: swapon () sets the swap area to the file or block device specified by path . swapoff () stops swapping to the file or block device specified by path . If the SWAP_FLAG_PREFER flag is specified in the swapon () swapflags argument, the new swap area will have a higher priority than default.

name: reboot
signature: int reboot(int magic1, int magic2, unsigned int cmd, void *arg)
returnDescription: For the values of op that stop or restart the system, a successful call to reboot () does not return. For the other op values, zero is returned on success.
notes: The reboot () call reboots the system, or enables/disables the reboot keystroke (abbreviated CAD, since the default is Ctrl-Alt- Delete; it can be changed using loadkeys(1) ).

name: sethostname
signature: int sethostname(char *name, int len)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls are used to access or to change the system hostname. More precisely, they operate on the hostname associated with the calling process's UTS namespace. sethostname () sets the hostname to the value given in the character array name .

name: setdomainname
signature: int setdomainname(char *name, int len)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These functions are used to access or to change the NIS domain name of the host system. More precisely, they operate on the NIS domain name associated with the calling process's UTS namespace. setdomainname () sets the domain name to the value given in the character array name .

name: init_module
signature: int init_module(void *umod, unsigned long len, const char *uargs)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: init_module () loads an ELF image into kernel space, performs any necessary symbol relocations, initializes module parameters to values provided by the caller, and then runs the module's init function. This system call requires privilege.

name: delete_module
signature: int delete_module(const char *name_user, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The delete_module () system call attempts to remove the unused loadable module entry identified by name . If the module has an exit function, then that function is executed before unloading the module. The flags argument is used to modify the behavior of the system call, as described below.

name: quotactl
signature: int quotactl(unsigned int cmd, const char *special, qid_t id, void *addr)
returnDescription: On success, quotactl () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The quota system can be used to set per-user, per-group, and per- project limits on the amount of disk space used on a filesystem. For each user and/or group, a soft limit and a hard limit can be set for each filesystem. The hard limit can't be exceeded.

name: gettid
signature: pid_t gettid(void)
returnDescription: On success, returns the thread ID of the calling thread.
notes: gettid () returns the caller's thread ID (TID). In a single- threaded process, the thread ID is equal to the process ID (PID, as returned by getpid(2) ). In a multithreaded process, all threads have the same PID, but each one has a unique TID.

name: readahead
description: Initiate file readahead into page cache
signature: int readahead(int fd, loff_t offset, size_t count)
returnDescription: On success, readahead () returns 0; on failure, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: readahead () initiates readahead on a file so that subsequent reads from that file will be satisfied from the cache, and not block on disk I/O (assuming the readahead was initiated early enough and that other activity on the system did not in the meantime flush pages from the cache).

name: setxattr
signature: int setxattr(const char *pathname, const char *name, const void *value, size_t size, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: lsetxattr
signature: int lsetxattr(const char *pathname, const char *name, const void *value, size_t size, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
