notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: fsetxattr
signature: int fsetxattr(int fd, const char *name, const void *value, size_t size, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: getxattr
signature: ssize_t getxattr(const char *pathname, const char *name, void *value, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return a nonnegative value which is the size (in bytes) of the extended attribute value. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: lgetxattr
signature: ssize_t lgetxattr(const char *pathname, const char *name, void *value, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return a nonnegative value which is the size (in bytes) of the extended attribute value. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: fgetxattr
signature: ssize_t fgetxattr(int fd, const char *name, void *value, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return a nonnegative value which is the size (in bytes) of the extended attribute value. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: listxattr
signature: ssize_t listxattr(const char *pathname, char *list, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, a nonnegative number is returned indicating the size of the extended attribute name list. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: llistxattr
signature: ssize_t llistxattr(const char *pathname, char *list, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, a nonnegative number is returned indicating the size of the extended attribute name list. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: flistxattr
signature: ssize_t flistxattr(int fd, char *list, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, a nonnegative number is returned indicating the size of the extended attribute name list. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: removexattr
signature: int removexattr(const char *pathname, const char *name)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: lremovexattr
signature: int lremovexattr(const char *pathname, const char *name)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: fremovexattr
signature: int fremovexattr(int fd, const char *name)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Extended attributes are name : value pairs associated with inodes (files, directories, symbolic links, etc.). They are extensions to the normal attributes which are associated with all inodes in the system (i.e., the stat(2) data).

name: tkill
description: Send a signal to a thread
signature: int tkill(pid_t pid, int sig)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: tgkill () sends the signal sig to the thread with the thread ID tid in the thread group tgid . (By contrast, kill(2) can be used to send a signal only to a process (i.e., thread group) as a whole, and the signal will be delivered to an arbitrary thread within that process.

name: time
signature: int time(old_time_t *tloc)
returnDescription: On success, the value of time in seconds since the Epoch is returned. On error, ((time_t) -1) is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: time () returns the time as the number of seconds since the Epoch, 1970-01-01 00:00:00 +0000 (UTC). If tloc is non-NULL, the return value is also stored in the memory pointed to by tloc .

name: futex
signature: int futex(uint32_t *uaddr, int op, uint32_t val, const struct timespec *utime, uint32_t *uaddr2, uint32_t val3)
returnDescription: On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The return value on success depends on the operation.
notes: The futex () system call provides a method for waiting until a certain condition becomes true. It is typically used as a blocking construct in the context of shared-memory synchronization. When using futexes, the majority of the synchronization operations are performed in user space.

name: sched_setaffinity
description: Set and get a thread's CPU affinity mask
signature: int sched_setaffinity(pid_t pid, unsigned int len, unsigned long *user_mask_ptr)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setaffinity () and sched_getaffinity () return 0 (but see "C library/kernel differences" below, which notes that the underlying sched_getaffinity () differs in its return value).
notes: A thread's CPU affinity mask determines the set of CPUs on which it is eligible to run. On a multiprocessor system, setting the CPU affinity mask can be used to obtain performance benefits. For example, by dedicating one CPU to a particular thread (i.e.

name: sched_getaffinity
description: Set and get a thread's CPU affinity mask
signature: int sched_getaffinity(pid_t pid, unsigned int len, unsigned long *user_mask_ptr)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setaffinity () and sched_getaffinity () return 0 (but see "C library/kernel differences" below, which notes that the underlying sched_getaffinity () differs in its return value).
notes: A thread's CPU affinity mask determines the set of CPUs on which it is eligible to run. On a multiprocessor system, setting the CPU affinity mask can be used to obtain performance benefits. For example, by dedicating one CPU to a particular thread (i.e.

name: io_setup
signature: int io_setup(unsigned nr_events, aio_context_t *ctxp)
returnDescription: On success, io_setup () returns 0. For the failure return, see VERSIONS.
notes: Note : this page describes the raw Linux system call interface. The wrapper function provided by libaio uses a different type for the ctx_idp argument. See VERSIONS. The io_setup () system call creates an asynchronous I/O context suitable for concurrently processing nr_events operations.

name: io_destroy
signature: int io_destroy(aio_context_t ctx)
returnDescription: On success, io_destroy () returns 0. For the failure return, see VERSIONS.
notes: Note : this page describes the raw Linux system call interface. The wrapper function provided by libaio uses a different type for the ctx_id argument. See VERSIONS.

name: io_getevents
description: Read asynchronous I/O events from the completion queue
signature: int io_getevents(aio_context_t ctx_id, long min_nr, long nr, struct io_event *events, struct timespec *timeout)
returnDescription: On success, io_getevents () returns the number of events read. This may be 0, or a value less than min_nr , if the timeout expired.
notes: Note : this page describes the raw Linux system call interface. The wrapper function provided by libaio uses a different type for the ctx_id argument. See VERSIONS.

name: io_submit
description: Submit asynchronous I/O blocks for processing
signature: int io_submit(aio_context_t ctx_id, long nr, struct iocb *iocbpp)
returnDescription: On success, io_submit () returns the number of iocb s submitted (which may be less than nr , or 0 if nr is zero). For the failure return, see VERSIONS.
notes: Note : this page describes the raw Linux system call interface. The wrapper function provided by libaio uses a different type for the ctx_id argument. See VERSIONS. The io_submit () system call queues nr I/O request blocks for processing in the AIO context ctx_id .

name: io_cancel
description: Cancel an outstanding asynchronous I/O operation
signature: int io_cancel(aio_context_t ctx_id, struct iocb *iocb, struct io_event *result)
returnDescription: On success, io_cancel () returns 0. For the failure return, see VERSIONS.
notes: Note : this page describes the raw Linux system call interface. The wrapper function provided by libaio uses a different type for the ctx_id argument. See VERSIONS. The io_cancel () system call attempts to cancel an asynchronous I/O operation previously submitted with io_submit(2) .

name: epoll_create
signature: int epoll_create(int size)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return a file descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: epoll_create () creates a new epoll(7) instance. Since Linux 2.6.8, the size argument is ignored, but must be greater than zero; see HISTORY. epoll_create () returns a file descriptor referring to the new epoll instance.

name: remap_file_pages
signature: int remap_file_pages(unsigned long start, unsigned long size, unsigned long prot, unsigned long pgoff, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, remap_file_pages () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Note : this system call was marked as deprecated starting with Linux 3.16. In Linux 4.0, the implementation was replaced by a slower in-kernel emulation. Those few applications that use this system call should consider migrating to alternatives.

name: getdents64
signature: int getdents64(unsigned int fd, struct linux_dirent64 *dirent, unsigned int count)
returnDescription: On success, the number of bytes read is returned. On end of directory, 0 is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These are not the interfaces you are interested in. Look at readdir(3) for the POSIX-conforming C library interface. This page documents the bare kernel system call interfaces.

name: set_tid_address
signature: int set_tid_address(int *tidptr)
returnDescription: set_tid_address () always returns the caller's thread ID.
notes: For each thread, the kernel maintains two attributes (addresses) called set_child_tid and clear_child_tid . These two attributes contain the value NULL by default.

name: restart_syscall
description: Restart a system call after interruption by a stop signal
signature: int restart_syscall(void)
returnDescription: The return value of restart_syscall () is the return value of whatever system call is being restarted.
notes: The restart_syscall () system call is used to restart certain system calls after a process that was stopped by a signal (e.g., SIGSTOP or SIGTSTP ) is later resumed after receiving a SIGCONT signal. This system call is designed only for internal use by the kernel.

name: semtimedop
signature: int semtimedop(int semid, struct sembuf *tsops, unsigned int nsops, const struct timespec *timeout)
returnDescription: On success, semop () and semtimedop () return 0. On failure, they return -1, and set errno to indicate the error.
notes: Each semaphore in a System V semaphore set has the following associated values: unsigned short semval; /* semaphore value */ unsigned short semzcnt; /* # waiting for zero */ unsigned short semncnt; /* # waiting for increase */ pid_t sempid; /* PID of process that last modified the semaphore value...

name: fadvise64
description: Predeclare an access pattern for file data
signature: int fadvise64(int fd, loff_t offset, size_t len, int advice)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, an error number is returned.
notes: Programs can use posix_fadvise () to announce an intention to access file data in a specific pattern in the future, thus allowing the kernel to perform appropriate optimizations.

name: timer_create
signature: int timer_create(const clockid_t which_clock, struct sigevent *timer_event_spec, timer_t *created_timer_id)
returnDescription: On success, timer_create () returns 0, and the ID of the new timer is placed in *timerid . On failure, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: timer_create () creates a new per-process interval timer. The ID of the new timer is returned in the buffer pointed to by timerid , which must be a non-null pointer. This ID is unique within the process, until the timer is deleted. The new timer is initially disarmed.

name: timer_settime
description: Arm/disarm and fetch state of POSIX per-process timer
signature: int timer_settime(timer_t timer_id, int flags, const struct itimerspec *new_setting, struct itimerspec *old_setting)
returnDescription: On success, timer_settime () and timer_gettime () return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: timer_settime () arms or disarms the timer identified by timerid . The new_value argument is pointer to an itimerspec structure that specifies the new initial value and the new interval for the timer. The itimerspec structure is described in itimerspec(3type) .

name: timer_gettime
description: Arm/disarm and fetch state of POSIX per-process timer
signature: int timer_gettime(timer_t timer_id, struct itimerspec *setting)
returnDescription: On success, timer_settime () and timer_gettime () return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: timer_settime () arms or disarms the timer identified by timerid . The new_value argument is pointer to an itimerspec structure that specifies the new initial value and the new interval for the timer. The itimerspec structure is described in itimerspec(3type) .

name: timer_getoverrun
description: Get overrun count for a POSIX per-process timer
signature: int timer_getoverrun(timer_t timer_id)
returnDescription: On success, timer_getoverrun () returns the overrun count of the specified timer; this count may be 0 if no overruns have occurred. On failure, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: timer_getoverrun () returns the "overrun count" for the timer referred to by timerid . An application can use the overrun count to accurately calculate the number of timer expirations that would have occurred over a given time interval.

name: timer_delete
signature: int timer_delete(timer_t timer_id)
returnDescription: On success, timer_delete () returns 0. On failure, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: timer_delete () deletes the timer whose ID is given in timerid . If the timer was armed at the time of this call, it is disarmed before being deleted. The treatment of any pending signal generated by the deleted timer is unspecified.

name: clock_settime
signature: int clock_settime(const clockid_t which_clock, const struct timespec *tp)
returnDescription: clock_gettime (), clock_settime (), and clock_getres () return 0 for success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The function clock_getres () finds the resolution (precision) of the specified clock clockid , and, if res is non-NULL, stores it in the struct timespec pointed to by res . The resolution of clocks depends on the implementation and cannot be configured by a particular process.

name: clock_gettime
signature: int clock_gettime(const clockid_t which_clock, struct timespec *tp)
returnDescription: clock_gettime (), clock_settime (), and clock_getres () return 0 for success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The function clock_getres () finds the resolution (precision) of the specified clock clockid , and, if res is non-NULL, stores it in the struct timespec pointed to by res . The resolution of clocks depends on the implementation and cannot be configured by a particular process.

name: clock_getres
signature: int clock_getres(const clockid_t which_clock, struct timespec *tp)
returnDescription: clock_gettime (), clock_settime (), and clock_getres () return 0 for success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The function clock_getres () finds the resolution (precision) of the specified clock clockid , and, if res is non-NULL, stores it in the struct timespec pointed to by res . The resolution of clocks depends on the implementation and cannot be configured by a particular process.

name: clock_nanosleep
signature: int clock_nanosleep(const clockid_t which_clock, int flags, const struct timespec *rqtp, struct timespec *rmtp)
returnDescription: On successfully sleeping for the requested interval, clock_nanosleep () returns 0.
notes: Like nanosleep(2) , clock_nanosleep () allows the calling thread to sleep for an interval specified with nanosecond precision.

name: exit_group
description: Exit all threads in a process
signature: void exit_group(int error_code)
returnDescription: This system call does not return.
notes: This system call terminates all threads in the calling process's thread group.

name: epoll_wait
description: Wait for an I/O event on an epoll file descriptor
signature: int epoll_wait(int epfd, struct epoll_event *events, int maxevents, int timeout)
returnDescription: On success, epoll_wait () returns the number of file descriptors ready for the requested I/O operation, or zero if no file descriptor became ready during the requested timeout milliseconds.
notes: The epoll_wait () system call waits for events on the epoll(7) instance referred to by the file descriptor epfd . The buffer pointed to by events is used to return information from the ready list about file descriptors in the interest list that have some events available.

name: epoll_ctl
description: Control interface for an epoll file descriptor
signature: int epoll_ctl(int epfd, int op, int fd, struct epoll_event *event)
returnDescription: When successful, epoll_ctl () returns zero. When an error occurs, epoll_ctl () returns -1 and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: This system call is used to add, modify, or remove entries in the interest list of the epoll(7) instance referred to by the file descriptor epfd . It requests that the operation op be performed for the target file descriptor, fd .

name: tgkill
description: Send a signal to a thread
signature: int tgkill(pid_t tgid, pid_t pid, int sig)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: tgkill () sends the signal sig to the thread with the thread ID tid in the thread group tgid . (By contrast, kill(2) can be used to send a signal only to a process (i.e., thread group) as a whole, and the signal will be delivered to an arbitrary thread within that process.

name: utimes
description: Change file last access and modification times
signature: int utimes(char *filename, struct old_timeval *utimes)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Note: modern applications may prefer to use the interfaces described in utimensat(2) . The utime () system call changes the access and modification times of the inode specified by path to the actime and modtime fields of times respectively.

name: mbind
description: Set memory policy for a memory range
signature: int mbind(unsigned long start, unsigned long len, unsigned long mode, const unsigned long *nmask, unsigned long maxnode, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, mbind () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mbind () sets the NUMA memory policy, which consists of a policy mode and zero or more nodes, for the memory range starting with addr and continuing for size bytes. The memory policy defines from which node memory is allocated.

name: set_mempolicy
description: Set default NUMA memory policy for a thread and its children
signature: int set_mempolicy(int mode, const unsigned long *nmask, unsigned long maxnode)
returnDescription: On success, set_mempolicy () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: set_mempolicy () sets the NUMA memory policy of the calling thread, which consists of a policy mode and zero or more nodes, to the values specified by the mode , nodemask , and maxnode arguments. A NUMA machine has different memory controllers with different distances to specific CPUs.

name: get_mempolicy
description: Retrieve NUMA memory policy for a thread
signature: int get_mempolicy(int *policy, unsigned long *nmask, unsigned long maxnode, unsigned long addr, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, get_mempolicy () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: get_mempolicy () retrieves the NUMA policy of the calling thread or of a memory address, depending on the setting of flags . A NUMA machine has different memory controllers with different distances to specific CPUs. The memory policy defines from which node memory is allocated for the thread.

name: mq_open
signature: int mq_open(const char *u_name, int oflag, umode_t mode, struct mq_attr *u_attr)
returnDescription: On success, mq_open () returns a message queue descriptor for use by other message queue functions. On error, mq_open () returns (mqd_t) -1 , with errno set to indicate the error.
notes: mq_open () creates a new POSIX message queue or opens an existing queue. The queue is identified by name . For details of the construction of name , see mq_overview(7) . The oflag argument specifies flags that control the operation of the call.

name: mq_unlink
signature: int mq_unlink(const char *u_name)
returnDescription: On success mq_unlink () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned, with errno set to indicate the error.
notes: mq_unlink () removes the specified message queue name . The message queue name is removed immediately. The queue itself is destroyed once any other processes that have the queue open close their descriptors referring to the queue.

name: mq_timedsend
description: Send a message to a message queue
signature: int mq_timedsend(mqd_t mqdes, const char *u_msg_ptr, size_t msg_len, unsigned int msg_prio, const struct timespec *u_abs_timeout)
returnDescription: On success, mq_send () and mq_timedsend () return zero; on error, -1 is returned, with errno set to indicate the error.
notes: mq_send () adds the message pointed to by msg_ptr to the message queue referred to by the message queue descriptor mqdes . The msg_len argument specifies the length of the message pointed to by msg_ptr ; this length must be less than or equal to the queue's mq_msgsize attribute.

name: mq_timedreceive
description: Receive a message from a message queue
signature: int mq_timedreceive(mqd_t mqdes, char *u_msg_ptr, size_t msg_len, unsigned int *u_msg_prio, const struct timespec *u_abs_timeout)
returnDescription: On success, mq_receive () and mq_timedreceive () return the number of bytes in the received message; on error, -1 is returned, with errno set to indicate the error.
notes: mq_receive () removes the oldest message with the highest priority from the message queue referred to by the message queue descriptor mqdes , and places it in the buffer pointed to by msg_ptr .

name: mq_notify
description: Register for notification when a message is available
signature: int mq_notify(mqd_t mqdes, const struct sigevent *u_notification)
returnDescription: On success mq_notify () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned, with errno set to indicate the error.
notes: mq_notify () allows the calling process to register or unregister for delivery of an asynchronous notification when a new message arrives on the empty message queue referred to by the message queue descriptor mqdes . The sevp argument is a pointer to a sigevent structure.

name: mq_getsetattr
signature: int mq_getsetattr(mqd_t mqdes, const struct mq_attr *u_mqstat, struct mq_attr *u_omqstat)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.
notes: Do not use this system call. This is the low-level system call used to implement mq_getattr(3) and mq_setattr(3) . For an explanation of how this system call operates, see the description of mq_setattr(3) .

name: kexec_load
description: Load a new kernel for later execution
signature: int kexec_load(unsigned long entry, unsigned long nr_segments, struct kexec_segment *segments, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The kexec_load () system call loads a new kernel that can be executed later by reboot(2) . The flags argument is a bit mask that controls the operation of the call. The following values can be specified in flags : KEXEC_ON_CRASH (since Linux 2.6.

name: waitid
description: Wait for process to change state
signature: pid_t waitid(int which, pid_t upid, struct siginfo *infop, int options, struct rusage *ru)
returnDescription: wait (): on success, returns the process ID of the terminated child; on failure, -1 is returned.
notes: All of these system calls are used to wait for state changes in a child of the calling process, and obtain information about the child whose state has changed. A state change is considered to be: the child terminated; the child was stopped by a signal; or the child was resumed by a signal.

name: add_key
description: Add a key to the kernel's key management facility
signature: int add_key(const char *_type, const char *_description, const void *_payload, size_t plen, key_serial_t ringid)
returnDescription: On success, add_key () returns the serial number of the key it created or updated. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: add_key () creates or updates a key of the given type and description , instantiates it with the payload of size size , attaches it to the nominated keyring , and returns the key's serial number. The key may be rejected if the provided data is in the wrong format or it is invalid in some other way.

name: request_key
description: Request a key from the kernel's key management facility
signature: int request_key(const char *_type, const char *_description, const char *_callout_info, key_serial_t destringid)
returnDescription: On success, request_key () returns the serial number of the key it found or caused to be created. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: request_key () attempts to find a key of the given type with a description (name) that matches the specified description . If such a key could not be found, then the key is optionally created.

name: keyctl
description: Manipulate the kernel's key management facility
signature: int keyctl(int option, unsigned long arg2, unsigned long arg3, unsigned long arg4, unsigned long arg5)
returnDescription: For a successful call, the return value depends on the operation. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: keyctl () allows user-space programs to perform key manipulation. The operation performed by keyctl () is determined by the value of the op argument.

name: ioprio_set
description: Get/set I/O scheduling class and priority
signature: int ioprio_set(int which, int who, int ioprio)
returnDescription: On success, ioprio_get () returns the ioprio value of the process with highest I/O priority of any of the processes that match the criteria specified in which and who .
notes: The ioprio_get () and ioprio_set () system calls get and set the I/O scheduling class and priority of one or more threads. The which and who arguments identify the thread(s) on which the system calls operate.

name: ioprio_get
description: Get/set I/O scheduling class and priority
signature: int ioprio_get(int which, int who)
returnDescription: On success, ioprio_get () returns the ioprio value of the process with highest I/O priority of any of the processes that match the criteria specified in which and who .
notes: The ioprio_get () and ioprio_set () system calls get and set the I/O scheduling class and priority of one or more threads. The which and who arguments identify the thread(s) on which the system calls operate.

name: inotify_init
signature: int inotify_init(void)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: For an overview of the inotify API, see inotify(7) . inotify_init () initializes a new inotify instance and returns a file descriptor associated with a new inotify event queue. If flags is 0, then inotify_init1 () is the same as inotify_init ().

name: inotify_add_watch
description: Add a watch to an initialized inotify instance
signature: int inotify_add_watch(int fd, const char *pathname, uint32_t mask)
returnDescription: On success, inotify_add_watch () returns a watch descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: inotify_add_watch () adds a new watch, or modifies an existing watch, for the file whose location is specified in path ; the caller must have read permission for this file. The fd argument is a file descriptor referring to the inotify instance whose watch list is to be modified.

name: inotify_rm_watch
description: Remove an existing watch from an inotify instance
signature: int inotify_rm_watch(int fd, int32_t wd)
returnDescription: On success, inotify_rm_watch () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: inotify_rm_watch () removes the watch associated with the watch descriptor wd from the inotify instance associated with the file descriptor fd . Removing a watch causes an IN_IGNORED event to be generated for this watch descriptor. (See inotify(7) .)

name: migrate_pages
description: Move all pages in a process to another set of nodes
signature: int migrate_pages(pid_t pid, unsigned long maxnode, const unsigned long *old_nodes, const unsigned long *new_nodes)
returnDescription: On success migrate_pages () returns the number of pages that could not be moved (i.e., a return of zero means that all pages were successfully moved).
notes: migrate_pages () attempts to move all pages of the process pid that are in memory nodes old_nodes to the memory nodes in new_nodes . Pages not located in any node in old_nodes will not be migrated.

name: openat
description: Open and possibly create a file
signature: int openat(int dfd, const char *filename, int flags, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: On success, open (), openat (), and creat () return the new file descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The open () system call opens the file specified by path . If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally (if O_CREAT is specified in flags ) be created by open ().

name: mkdirat
signature: int mkdirat(int dfd, const char *pathname, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: mkdir () and mkdirat () return zero on success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mkdir () attempts to create a directory named path . The argument mode specifies the mode for the new directory (see inode(7) ). It is modified by the process's umask in the usual way: in the absence of a default ACL, the mode of the created directory is ( mode & ~ umask & 0777).

name: mknodat
description: Create a special or ordinary file
signature: int mknodat(int dfd, const char *filename, umode_t mode, unsigned int dev)
returnDescription: mknod () and mknodat () return zero on success. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The system call mknod () creates a filesystem node (file, device special file, or named pipe) named path , with attributes specified by mode and dev . The mode argument specifies both the file mode to use and the type of node to be created.

name: fchownat
signature: int fchownat(int dfd, const char *filename, uid_t user, gid_t group, int flag)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls change the owner and group of a file. The chown (), fchown (), and lchown () system calls differ only in how the file is specified: â¢ chown () changes the ownership of the file specified by path , which is dereferenced if it is a symbolic link.

name: futimesat
description: Change timestamps of a file relative to a directory file descriptor
signature: int futimesat(int dfd, const char *filename, struct old_timeval *utimes)
returnDescription: On success, futimesat () returns a 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: This system call is obsolete. Use utimensat(2) instead. The futimesat () system call operates in exactly the same way as utimes(2) , except for the differences described in this manual page.

name: newfstatat
signature: int newfstatat(int dfd, const char *filename, struct stat *statbuf, int flag)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These functions return information about a file, in the buffer pointed to by statbuf . No permissions are required on the file itself, butâin the case of stat (), fstatat (), and lstat ()âexecute (search) permission is required on all of the directories in path that lead to the file.

name: unlinkat
description: Delete a name and possibly the file it refers to
signature: int unlinkat(int dfd, const char *pathname, int flag)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: unlink () deletes a name from the filesystem. If that name was the last link to a file and no processes have the file open, the file is deleted and the space it was using is made available for reuse.

name: renameat
description: Change the name or location of a file
signature: int renameat(int olddfd, const char *oldname, int newdfd, const char *newname)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: rename () renames a file, moving it between directories if required. Any other hard links to the file (as created using link(2) ) are unaffected. Open file descriptors for oldpath are also unaffected. Various restrictions determine whether or not the rename operation succeeds: see ERRORS below.

name: linkat
description: Make a new name for a file
signature: int linkat(int olddfd, const char *oldname, int newdfd, const char *newname, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: link () creates a new link (also known as a hard link) to an existing file. If newpath exists, it will not be overwritten.

name: symlinkat
description: Make a new name for a file
signature: int symlinkat(const char *oldname, int newdfd, const char *newname)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: symlink () creates a symbolic link named linkpath which contains the string target . Symbolic links are interpreted at run time as if the contents of the link had been substituted into the path being followed to find a file or directory. Symbolic links may contain ..

name: readlinkat
description: Read value of a symbolic link
signature: ssize_t readlinkat(int dfd, const char *pathname, char *buf, int bufsiz)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return the number of bytes placed in buf . (If the returned value equals bufsiz , then truncation may have occurred.
notes: readlink () places the contents of the symbolic link path in the buffer buf , which has size bufsiz . readlink () does not append a terminating null byte to buf . It will (silently) truncate the contents (to a length of bufsiz characters), in case the buffer is too small to hold all of the contents.

name: fchmodat
signature: int fchmodat(int dfd, const char *filename, umode_t mode)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The chmod () and fchmod () system calls change a file's mode bits. (The file mode consists of the file permission bits plus the set- user-ID, set-group-ID, and sticky bits.

name: faccessat
description: Check user's permissions for a file
signature: int faccessat(int dfd, const char *filename, int mode)
returnDescription: On success (all requested permissions granted, or mode is F_OK and the file exists), zero is returned.
notes: access () checks whether the calling process can access the file path . If path is a symbolic link, it is dereferenced. The mode specifies the accessibility check(s) to be performed, and is either the value F_OK , or a mask consisting of the bitwise OR of one or more of R_OK , W_OK , and X_OK .

name: pselect6
signature: int pselect6(int n, fd_set *inp, fd_set *outp, fd_set *exp, struct timespec *tsp, void *sig)
returnDescription: On success, select () and pselect () return the number of file descriptors contained in the three returned descriptor sets (that is, the total number of bits that are set in readfds , writefds , ex...
notes: WARNING : select () can monitor only file descriptors numbers that are less than FD_SETSIZE (1024)âan unreasonably low limit for many modern applicationsâand this limitation will not change. All modern applications should instead use poll(2) or epoll(7) , which do not suffer this limitation.

name: ppoll
description: Wait for some event on a file descriptor
signature: int ppoll(struct pollfd *ufds, unsigned int nfds, struct timespec *tsp, const sigset_t *sigmask, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: On success, poll () returns a nonnegative value which is the number of elements in the pollfds whose revents fields have been set to a nonzero value (indicating an event or an error).
notes: poll () performs a similar task to select(2) : it waits for one of a set of file descriptors to become ready to perform I/O. The Linux-specific epoll(7) API performs a similar task, but offers features beyond those found in poll ().

name: unshare
description: Disassociate parts of the process execution context
signature: int unshare(unsigned long unshare_flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: unshare () allows a process (or thread) to disassociate parts of its execution context that are currently being shared with other processes (or threads).

name: set_robust_list
signature: int set_robust_list(struct robust_list_head *head, size_t len)
returnDescription: The set_robust_list () and get_robust_list () system calls return zero when the operation is successful, an error code otherwise.
notes: These system calls deal with per-thread robust futex lists. These lists are managed in user space: the kernel knows only about the location of the head of the list. A thread can inform the kernel of the location of its robust futex list using set_robust_list ().

name: get_robust_list
signature: int get_robust_list(int pid, struct robust_list_head *head_ptr, size_t *len_ptr)
returnDescription: The set_robust_list () and get_robust_list () system calls return zero when the operation is successful, an error code otherwise.
notes: These system calls deal with per-thread robust futex lists. These lists are managed in user space: the kernel knows only about the location of the head of the list. A thread can inform the kernel of the location of its robust futex list using set_robust_list ().

name: splice
signature: ssize_t splice(int fd_in, loff_t *off_in, int fd_out, loff_t *off_out, size_t len, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: Upon successful completion, splice () returns the number of bytes spliced to or from the pipe. A return value of 0 means end of input.
notes: splice () moves data between two file descriptors without copying between kernel address space and user address space. It transfers up to size bytes of data from the file descriptor fd_in to the file descriptor fd_out , where one of the file descriptors must refer to a pipe.

name: tee
signature: ssize_t tee(int fdin, int fdout, size_t len, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: Upon successful completion, tee () returns the number of bytes that were duplicated between the input and output.
notes: tee () duplicates up to size bytes of data from the pipe referred to by the file descriptor fd_in to the pipe referred to by the file descriptor fd_out . It does not consume the data that is duplicated from fd_in ; therefore, that data can be copied by a subsequent splice(2) .

name: sync_file_range
description: Sync a file segment with disk
signature: int sync_file_range(int fd, loff_t offset, loff_t nbytes, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, sync_file_range () returns 0; on failure -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sync_file_range () permits fine control when synchronizing the open file referred to by the file descriptor fd with disk. offset is the starting byte of the file range to be synchronized.

name: vmsplice
description: Splice user pages to/from a pipe
signature: ssize_t vmsplice(int fd, const struct iovec *uiov, unsigned long nr_segs, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: Upon successful completion, vmsplice () returns the number of bytes transferred to the pipe. On error, vmsplice () returns -1 and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: If fd is opened for writing, the vmsplice () system call maps nr_segs ranges of user memory described by iov into a pipe. If fd is opened for reading, the vmsplice () system call fills nr_segs ranges of user memory described by iov from a pipe. The file descriptor fd must refer to a pipe.

name: move_pages
description: Move individual pages of a process to another node
signature: int move_pages(pid_t pid, unsigned long nr_pages, const void *pages, const int *nodes, int *status, int flags)
returnDescription: On success move_pages () returns zero. On error, it returns -1, and sets errno to indicate the error. If positive value is returned, it is the number of nonmigrated pages.
notes: move_pages () moves the specified pages of the process pid to the memory nodes specified by nodes . The result of the move is reflected in status . The flags indicate constraints on the pages to be moved. pid is the ID of the process in which pages are to be moved.

name: utimensat
description: Change file timestamps with nanosecond precision
signature: int utimensat(int dfd, const char *filename, struct timespec *utimes, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, utimensat () and futimens () return 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: utimensat () and futimens () update the timestamps of a file with nanosecond precision. This contrasts with the historical utime(2) and utimes(2) , which permit only second and microsecond precision, respectively, when setting file timestamps.

name: epoll_pwait
description: Wait for an I/O event on an epoll file descriptor
signature: int epoll_pwait(int epfd, struct epoll_event *events, int maxevents, int timeout, const sigset_t *sigmask, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: On success, epoll_wait () returns the number of file descriptors ready for the requested I/O operation, or zero if no file descriptor became ready during the requested timeout milliseconds.
notes: The epoll_wait () system call waits for events on the epoll(7) instance referred to by the file descriptor epfd . The buffer pointed to by events is used to return information from the ready list about file descriptors in the interest list that have some events available.

name: signalfd
description: Create a file descriptor for accepting signals
signature: int signalfd(int ufd, sigset_t *user_mask, size_t sizemask)
returnDescription: On success, signalfd () returns a signalfd file descriptor; this is either a new file descriptor (if fd was -1), or fd if fd was a valid signalfd file descriptor.
notes: signalfd () creates a file descriptor that can be used to accept signals targeted at the caller. This provides an alternative to the use of a signal handler or sigwaitinfo(2) , and has the advantage that the file descriptor may be monitored by select(2) , poll(2) , and epoll(7) .

name: timerfd_create
description: Timers that notify via file descriptors
signature: int timerfd_create(int clockid, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, timerfd_create () returns a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls create and operate on a timer that delivers timer expiration notifications via a file descriptor. They provide an alternative to the use of setitimer(2) or timer_create(2) , with the advantage that the file descriptor may be monitored by select(2) , poll(2) , and epoll(7) .

name: eventfd
description: Create a file descriptor for event notification
signature: int eventfd(unsigned int count)
returnDescription: On success, eventfd () returns a new eventfd file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: eventfd () creates an "eventfd object" that can be used as an event wait/notify mechanism by user-space applications, and by the kernel to notify user-space applications of events. The object contains an unsigned 64-bit integer ( uint64_t ) counter that is maintained by the kernel.

name: fallocate
signature: int fallocate(int fd, int mode, loff_t offset, loff_t len)
returnDescription: On success, fallocate () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: This is a nonportable, Linux-specific system call. For the portable, POSIX.1-specified method of ensuring that space is allocated for a file, see posix_fallocate(3) .

name: timerfd_settime
description: Timers that notify via file descriptors
signature: int timerfd_settime(int ufd, int flags, const struct itimerspec *utmr, struct itimerspec *otmr)
returnDescription: On success, timerfd_create () returns a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls create and operate on a timer that delivers timer expiration notifications via a file descriptor. They provide an alternative to the use of setitimer(2) or timer_create(2) , with the advantage that the file descriptor may be monitored by select(2) , poll(2) , and epoll(7) .

name: timerfd_gettime
description: Timers that notify via file descriptors
signature: int timerfd_gettime(int ufd, struct itimerspec *otmr)
returnDescription: On success, timerfd_create () returns a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These system calls create and operate on a timer that delivers timer expiration notifications via a file descriptor. They provide an alternative to the use of setitimer(2) or timer_create(2) , with the advantage that the file descriptor may be monitored by select(2) , poll(2) , and epoll(7) .

name: accept4
description: Accept a connection on a socket
signature: int accept4(int fd, struct sockaddr *upeer_sockaddr, int *upeer_addrlen, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return a file descriptor for the accepted socket (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and addrlen is left unchanged.
notes: The accept () system call is used with connection-based socket types ( SOCK_STREAM , SOCK_SEQPACKET ).

name: signalfd4
description: Create a file descriptor for accepting signals
signature: int signalfd4(int ufd, sigset_t *user_mask, size_t sizemask, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, signalfd () returns a signalfd file descriptor; this is either a new file descriptor (if fd was -1), or fd if fd was a valid signalfd file descriptor.
notes: signalfd () creates a file descriptor that can be used to accept signals targeted at the caller. This provides an alternative to the use of a signal handler or sigwaitinfo(2) , and has the advantage that the file descriptor may be monitored by select(2) , poll(2) , and epoll(7) .

name: eventfd2
description: Create a file descriptor for event notification
signature: int eventfd2(unsigned int count, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, eventfd () returns a new eventfd file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: eventfd () creates an "eventfd object" that can be used as an event wait/notify mechanism by user-space applications, and by the kernel to notify user-space applications of events. The object contains an unsigned 64-bit integer ( uint64_t ) counter that is maintained by the kernel.

name: epoll_create1
signature: int epoll_create1(int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return a file descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: epoll_create () creates a new epoll(7) instance. Since Linux 2.6.8, the size argument is ignored, but must be greater than zero; see HISTORY. epoll_create () returns a file descriptor referring to the new epoll instance.

name: dup3
signature: int dup3(unsigned int oldfd, unsigned int newfd, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return the new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The dup () system call allocates a new file descriptor that refers to the same open file description as the descriptor oldfd . (For an explanation of open file descriptions, see open(2) .

name: pipe2
signature: int pipe2(int *fildes, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and pipefd is left unchanged. On Linux (and other systems), pipe () does not modify pipefd on failure.
notes: pipe () creates a pipe, a unidirectional data channel that can be used for interprocess communication. The array pipefd is used to return two file descriptors referring to the ends of the pipe. pipefd[0] refers to the read end of the pipe. pipefd[1] refers to the write end of the pipe.

name: inotify_init1
signature: int inotify_init1(int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: For an overview of the inotify API, see inotify(7) . inotify_init () initializes a new inotify instance and returns a file descriptor associated with a new inotify event queue. If flags is 0, then inotify_init1 () is the same as inotify_init ().

name: preadv
description: Read or write data into multiple buffers
signature: ssize_t preadv(unsigned long fd, const struct iovec *vec, unsigned long vlen, unsigned long pos_l, unsigned long pos_h)
returnDescription: On success, readv (), preadv (), and preadv2 () return the number of bytes read; writev (), pwritev (), and pwritev2 () return the number of bytes written.
notes: The readv () system call reads iovcnt buffers from the file associated with the file descriptor fd into the buffers described by iov ("scatter input"). The writev () system call writes iovcnt buffers of data described by iov to the file associated with the file descriptor fd ("gather output").

name: pwritev
description: Read or write data into multiple buffers
signature: ssize_t pwritev(unsigned long fd, const struct iovec *vec, unsigned long vlen, unsigned long pos_l, unsigned long pos_h)
returnDescription: On success, readv (), preadv (), and preadv2 () return the number of bytes read; writev (), pwritev (), and pwritev2 () return the number of bytes written.
notes: The readv () system call reads iovcnt buffers from the file associated with the file descriptor fd into the buffers described by iov ("scatter input"). The writev () system call writes iovcnt buffers of data described by iov to the file associated with the file descriptor fd ("gather output").

name: rt_tgsigqueueinfo
signature: int rt_tgsigqueueinfo(pid_t tgid, pid_t pid, int sig, siginfo_t *uinfo)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, they return -1 and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The rt_sigqueueinfo () and rt_tgsigqueueinfo () system calls are the low-level interfaces used to send a signal plus data to a process or thread. The receiver of the signal can obtain the accompanying data by establishing a signal handler with the sigaction(2) SA_SIGINFO flag.

name: perf_event_open
signature: int perf_event_open(struct perf_event_attr *attr_uptr, pid_t pid, int cpu, int group_fd, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, perf_event_open () returns the new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Given a list of parameters, perf_event_open () returns a file descriptor, for use in subsequent system calls ( read(2) , mmap(2) , prctl(2) , fcntl(2) , etc.). A call to perf_event_open () creates a file descriptor that allows measuring performance information.

name: recvmmsg
description: Receive multiple messages on a socket
signature: int recvmmsg(int fd, struct mmsghdr *mmsg, unsigned int vlen, unsigned int flags, struct timespec *timeout)
returnDescription: On success, recvmmsg () returns the number of messages received in msgvec ; on error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The recvmmsg () system call is an extension of recvmsg(2) that allows the caller to receive multiple messages from a socket using a single system call. (This has performance benefits for some applications.) A further extension over recvmsg(2) is support for a timeout on the receive operation.

name: fanotify_init
signature: int fanotify_init(unsigned int flags, unsigned int event_f_flags)
returnDescription: On success, fanotify_init () returns a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: For an overview of the fanotify API, see fanotify(7) . fanotify_init () initializes a new fanotify group and returns a file descriptor for the event queue associated with the group.

name: fanotify_mark
description: Add, remove, or modify an fanotify mark on a filesystem object
signature: int fanotify_mark(int fanotify_fd, unsigned int flags, uint64_t mask, int dfd, const char *pathname)
returnDescription: On success, fanotify_mark () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: For an overview of the fanotify API, see fanotify(7) . fanotify_mark () adds, removes, or modifies an fanotify mark on a filesystem object. The caller must have read permission on the filesystem object that is to be marked. The fanotify_fd argument is a file descriptor returned by fanotify_init(2) .

name: prlimit64
signature: int prlimit64(pid_t pid, unsigned int resource, const struct rlimit64 *new_rlim, struct rlimit64 *old_rlim)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The getrlimit () and setrlimit () system calls get and set resource limits. Each resource has an associated soft and hard limit, as defined by the rlimit structure. The soft limit is the value that the kernel enforces for the corresponding resource.

name: name_to_handle_at
description: Obtain handle for a pathname and open file via a handle
signature: int name_to_handle_at(int dfd, const char *name, struct file_handle *handle, void *mnt_id, int flag)
returnDescription: On success, name_to_handle_at () returns 0, and open_by_handle_at () returns a file descriptor (a nonnegative integer).
notes: The name_to_handle_at () and open_by_handle_at () system calls split the functionality of openat(2) into two parts: name_to_handle_at () returns an opaque handle that corresponds to a specified file; open_by_handle_at () opens the file corresponding to a handle returned by a previous call to name...

name: open_by_handle_at
description: Obtain handle for a pathname and open file via a handle
signature: int open_by_handle_at(int mountdirfd, struct file_handle *handle, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, name_to_handle_at () returns 0, and open_by_handle_at () returns a file descriptor (a nonnegative integer).
notes: The name_to_handle_at () and open_by_handle_at () system calls split the functionality of openat(2) into two parts: name_to_handle_at () returns an opaque handle that corresponds to a specified file; open_by_handle_at () opens the file corresponding to a handle returned by a previous call to name...

name: clock_adjtime
signature: int clock_adjtime(const clockid_t which_clock, struct timex *utx)
returnDescription: On success, adjtimex () and ntp_adjtime () return the clock state; that is, one of the following values: TIME_OK Clock synchronized, no leap second adjustment pending.
notes: Linux uses David L. Mills' clock adjustment algorithm (see RFC 5905). The system call adjtimex () reads and optionally sets adjustment parameters for this algorithm.

name: syncfs
signature: int syncfs(int fd)
returnDescription: syncfs () returns 0 on success; on error, it returns -1 and sets errno to indicate the error.
notes: sync () causes all pending modifications to filesystem metadata and cached file data to be written to the underlying filesystems. syncfs () is like sync (), but synchronizes just the filesystem containing file referred to by the open file descriptor fd .

name: sendmmsg
description: Send multiple messages on a socket
signature: int sendmmsg(int fd, struct mmsghdr *mmsg, unsigned int vlen, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, sendmmsg () returns the number of messages sent from msgvec ; if this is less than n , the caller can retry with a further sendmmsg () call to send the remaining messages.
notes: The sendmmsg () system call is an extension of sendmsg(2) that allows the caller to transmit multiple messages on a socket using a single system call. (This has performance benefits for some applications.) The sockfd argument is the file descriptor of the socket on which data is to be transmitted.

name: setns
signature: int setns(int fd, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, setns () returns 0. On failure, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The setns () system call allows the calling thread to move into different namespaces. The fd argument is one of the following: â¢ a file descriptor referring to one of the magic links in a /proc/ pid /ns/ directory (or a bind mount to such a link); â¢ a PID file descriptor (see pidfd_open(2) ).

name: getcpu
description: Determine CPU and NUMA node on which the calling thread is running
signature: int getcpu(unsigned *cpup, unsigned *nodep, struct getcpu_cache *unused)
returnDescription: On success, 0 is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The getcpu () system call identifies the processor and node on which the calling thread or process is currently running and writes them into the integers pointed to by the cpu and node arguments. The processor is a unique small integer identifying a CPU.

name: process_vm_readv
description: Transfer data between process address spaces
signature: ssize_t process_vm_readv(pid_t pid, const struct iovec *lvec, unsigned long liovcnt, const struct iovec *rvec, unsigned long riovcnt, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, process_vm_readv () returns the number of bytes read and process_vm_writev () returns the number of bytes written.
notes: These system calls transfer data between the address space of the calling process ("the local process") and the process identified by pid ("the remote process"). The data moves directly between the address spaces of the two processes, without passing through kernel space.

name: process_vm_writev
description: Transfer data between process address spaces
signature: ssize_t process_vm_writev(pid_t pid, const struct iovec *lvec, unsigned long liovcnt, const struct iovec *rvec, unsigned long riovcnt, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, process_vm_readv () returns the number of bytes read and process_vm_writev () returns the number of bytes written.
notes: These system calls transfer data between the address space of the calling process ("the local process") and the process identified by pid ("the remote process"). The data moves directly between the address spaces of the two processes, without passing through kernel space.

name: kcmp
description: Compare two processes to determine if they share a kernel resource
signature: int kcmp(pid_t pid1, pid_t pid2, int type, unsigned long idx1, unsigned long idx2)
returnDescription: The return value of a successful call to kcmp () is simply the result of arithmetic comparison of kernel pointers (when the kernel compares resources, it uses their memory addresses).
notes: The kcmp () system call can be used to check whether the two processes identified by pid1 and pid2 share a kernel resource such as virtual memory, file descriptors, and so on.

name: finit_module
signature: int finit_module(int fd, const char *uargs, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: init_module () loads an ELF image into kernel space, performs any necessary symbol relocations, initializes module parameters to values provided by the caller, and then runs the module's init function. This system call requires privilege.

name: sched_setattr
description: Set and get scheduling policy and attributes
signature: int sched_setattr(pid_t pid, struct sched_attr *uattr, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setattr () and sched_getattr () return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sched_setattr() The sched_setattr () system call sets the scheduling policy and associated attributes for the thread whose ID is specified in pid . If pid equals zero, the scheduling policy and attributes of the calling thread will be set. Currently, Linux supports the following "normal" (i.e.

name: sched_getattr
description: Set and get scheduling policy and attributes
signature: int sched_getattr(pid_t pid, struct sched_attr *uattr, unsigned int usize, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, sched_setattr () and sched_getattr () return 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: sched_setattr() The sched_setattr () system call sets the scheduling policy and associated attributes for the thread whose ID is specified in pid . If pid equals zero, the scheduling policy and attributes of the calling thread will be set. Currently, Linux supports the following "normal" (i.e.

name: renameat2
description: Change the name or location of a file
signature: int renameat2(int olddfd, const char *oldname, int newdfd, const char *newname, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: rename () renames a file, moving it between directories if required. Any other hard links to the file (as created using link(2) ) are unaffected. Open file descriptors for oldpath are also unaffected. Various restrictions determine whether or not the rename operation succeeds: see ERRORS below.

name: seccomp
description: Operate on Secure Computing state of the process
signature: int seccomp(unsigned int op, unsigned int flags, void *uargs)
returnDescription: On success, seccomp () returns 0. On error, if SECCOMP_FILTER_FLAG_TSYNC was used, the return value is the ID of the thread that caused the synchronization failure.
notes: The seccomp () system call operates on the Secure Computing (seccomp) state of the calling process. Currently, Linux supports the following operation values: SECCOMP_SET_MODE_STRICT The only system calls that the calling thread is permitted to make are read(2) , write(2) , _exit(2) (but not exit_...

name: getrandom
description: Obtain a series of random bytes
signature: ssize_t getrandom(char *ubuf, size_t len, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, getrandom () returns the number of bytes that were copied to the buffer buf .
notes: The getrandom () system call fills the buffer pointed to by buf with up to size random bytes. These bytes can be used to seed user-space random number generators or for cryptographic purposes. By default, getrandom () draws entropy from the urandom source (i.e.

name: memfd_create
signature: int memfd_create(const char *uname, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, memfd_create () returns a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: memfd_create () creates an anonymous file and returns a file descriptor that refers to it. The file behaves like a regular file, and so can be modified, truncated, memory-mapped, and so on. However, unlike a regular file, it lives in RAM and has a volatile backing storage.

name: kexec_file_load
description: Load a new kernel for later execution
signature: int kexec_file_load(int kernel_fd, int initrd_fd, unsigned long cmdline_len, const char *cmdline_ptr, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The kexec_load () system call loads a new kernel that can be executed later by reboot(2) . The flags argument is a bit mask that controls the operation of the call. The following values can be specified in flags : KEXEC_ON_CRASH (since Linux 2.6.

name: bpf
description: Perform a command on an extended BPF map or program
signature: int bpf(int cmd, union bpf_attr *uattr, unsigned int size)
returnDescription: For a successful call, the return value depends on the operation: BPF_MAP_CREATE The new file descriptor associated with the eBPF map.
notes: The bpf () system call performs a range of operations related to extended Berkeley Packet Filters. Extended BPF (or eBPF) is similar to the original ("classic") BPF (cBPF) used to filter network packets.

name: execveat
description: Execute program relative to a directory file descriptor
signature: int execveat(int fd, const char *filename, const char *const *argv, const char *const *envp, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, execveat () does not return. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The execveat () system call executes the program referred to by the combination of dirfd and path . It operates in exactly the same way as execve(2) , except for the differences described in this manual page.

name: userfaultfd
description: Create a file descriptor for handling page faults in user space
signature: int userfaultfd(int flags)
returnDescription: On success, userfaultfd () returns a new file descriptor that refers to the userfaultfd object. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: userfaultfd () creates a new userfaultfd object that can be used for delegation of page-fault handling to a user-space application, and returns a file descriptor that refers to the new object. The new userfaultfd object is configured using ioctl(2) .

name: membarrier
description: Issue memory barriers on a set of threads
signature: int membarrier(int cmd, unsigned int flags, int cpu_id)
returnDescription: On success, the MEMBARRIER_CMD_QUERY operation returns a bit mask of supported commands, and the MEMBARRIER_CMD_GLOBAL , MEMBARRIER_CMD_GLOBAL_EXPEDITED , MEMBARRIER_CMD_REGISTER_GLOBAL_EXPEDITED ,...
notes: The membarrier () system call helps reducing the overhead of the memory barrier instructions required to order memory accesses on multi-core systems.

name: mlock2
signature: int mlock2(unsigned long start, size_t len, int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these system calls return 0. On error, -1 is returned, errno is set to indicate the error, and no changes are made to any locks in the address space of the process.
notes: mlock (), mlock2 (), and mlockall () lock part or all of the calling process's virtual address space into RAM, preventing that memory from being paged to the swap area.

name: copy_file_range
description: Copy a range of data from one file to another
signature: ssize_t copy_file_range(int fd_in, loff_t *off_in, int fd_out, loff_t *off_out, size_t len, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: Upon successful completion, copy_file_range () will return the number of bytes copied between files. This could be less than the size originally requested.
notes: The copy_file_range () system call performs an in-kernel copy between two file descriptors without the additional cost of transferring data from the kernel to user space and then back into the kernel.

name: preadv2
description: Read or write data into multiple buffers
signature: ssize_t preadv2(unsigned long fd, const struct iovec *vec, unsigned long vlen, unsigned long pos_l, unsigned long pos_h, rwf_t flags)
returnDescription: On success, readv (), preadv (), and preadv2 () return the number of bytes read; writev (), pwritev (), and pwritev2 () return the number of bytes written.
notes: The readv () system call reads iovcnt buffers from the file associated with the file descriptor fd into the buffers described by iov ("scatter input"). The writev () system call writes iovcnt buffers of data described by iov to the file associated with the file descriptor fd ("gather output").

name: pwritev2
description: Read or write data into multiple buffers
signature: ssize_t pwritev2(unsigned long fd, const struct iovec *vec, unsigned long vlen, unsigned long pos_l, unsigned long pos_h, rwf_t flags)
returnDescription: On success, readv (), preadv (), and preadv2 () return the number of bytes read; writev (), pwritev (), and pwritev2 () return the number of bytes written.
notes: The readv () system call reads iovcnt buffers from the file associated with the file descriptor fd into the buffers described by iov ("scatter input"). The writev () system call writes iovcnt buffers of data described by iov to the file associated with the file descriptor fd ("gather output").

name: pkey_mprotect
description: Set protection on a region of memory
signature: int pkey_mprotect(unsigned long start, size_t len, unsigned long prot, int pkey)
returnDescription: On success, mprotect () and pkey_mprotect () return zero. On error, these system calls return -1, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: mprotect () changes the access protections for the calling process's memory pages containing any part of the address range in the interval [ addr , addr + size -1]. addr must be aligned to a page boundary.

name: pkey_alloc
description: Allocate or free a protection key
signature: int pkey_alloc(unsigned long flags, unsigned long init_val)
returnDescription: On success, pkey_alloc () returns a positive protection key value. On success, pkey_free () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: pkey_alloc () allocates a protection key (pkey) and allows it to be passed to pkey_mprotect(2) . The pkey_alloc () flags is reserved for future use and currently must always be specified as 0.

name: pkey_free
description: Allocate or free a protection key
signature: int pkey_free(int pkey)
returnDescription: On success, pkey_alloc () returns a positive protection key value. On success, pkey_free () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: pkey_alloc () allocates a protection key (pkey) and allows it to be passed to pkey_mprotect(2) . The pkey_alloc () flags is reserved for future use and currently must always be specified as 0.

name: statx
signature: int statx(int dfd, const char *filename, unsigned flags, unsigned int mask, struct statx *buffer)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: This function returns information about a file, storing it in the buffer pointed to by statxbuf . The returned buffer is a structure of the following type: struct statx { __u32 stx_mask; /* Mask of bits indicating filled fields */ __u32 stx_blksize; /* Block size for filesystem I/O */ __u64 stx_a...

name: io_pgetevents
signature: int io_pgetevents(aio_context_t ctx_id, long min_nr, long nr, struct io_event *events, struct timespec *timeout, const struct __aio_sigset *usig)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: rseq
signature: int rseq(struct rseq *rseq, uint32_t rseq_len, int flags, uint32_t sig)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: pidfd_send_signal
description: Send a signal to a process specified by a file descriptor
signature: int pidfd_send_signal(int pidfd, int sig, siginfo_t *info, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, pidfd_send_signal () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The pidfd_send_signal () system call sends the signal sig to the target process referred to by pidfd , a PID file descriptor that refers to a process. If the info argument points to a siginfo_t buffer, that buffer should be populated as described in rt_sigqueueinfo(2) .

name: io_uring_setup
description: Setup a context for performing asynchronous I/O
signature: int io_uring_setup(uint32_t entries, struct io_uring_params *params)
returnDescription: io_uring_setup(2) returns a new file descriptor on success.
notes: The io_uring_setup(2) system call sets up a submission queue (SQ) and completion queue (CQ) with at least entries entries, and returns a file descriptor which can be used to perform subsequent operations on the io_uring instance.

name: io_uring_enter
signature: int io_uring_enter(unsigned int fd, uint32_t to_submit, uint32_t min_complete, uint32_t flags, const void *argp, size_t argsz)
returnDescription: io_uring_enter(2) returns the number of I/Os successfully consumed. This can be zero if to_submit was zero or if the submission queue was empty.
notes: io_uring_enter(2) is used to initiate and complete I/O using the shared submission and completion queues setup by a call to io_uring_setup(2) . A single call can both submit new I/O and wait for completions of I/O initiated by this call or previous calls to io_uring_enter(2) .

name: io_uring_register
description: Register files or user buffers for asynchronous I/O
signature: int io_uring_register(unsigned int fd, unsigned int opcode, void *arg, unsigned int nr_args)
returnDescription: On success, io_uring_register(2) returns either 0 or a positive value, depending on the opcode used. On error, a negative error value is returned. The caller should not rely on the errno variable.
notes: The io_uring_register(2) system call registers resources (e.g. user buffers, files, eventfd, personality, restrictions) for use in an io_uring(7) instance referenced by fd .

name: open_tree
description: Open path or create detached mount object and attach to fd
signature: int open_tree(int dfd, const char *filename, unsigned flags)
returnDescription: On success, a new file descriptor is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The open_tree () system call is part of the suite of file- descriptor-based mount facilities in Linux. â¢ If flags contains OPEN_TREE_CLONE , open_tree () creates a detached mount object which consists of a bind-mount of the path specified by the path .

name: move_mount
description: Move or attach mount object to filesystem
signature: int move_mount(int from_dfd, const char *from_pathname, int to_dfd, const char *to_pathname, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, move_mount () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The move_mount () system call is part of the suite of file- descriptor-based mount facilities in Linux. move_mount () moves the mount object indicated by from_dirfd and from_path to the path indicated by to_dirfd and to_path .

name: fsopen
signature: int fsopen(const char *_fs_name, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, a new file descriptor is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The fsopen () system call is part of the suite of file-descriptor- based mount facilities in Linux. fsopen () creates a blank filesystem configuration context within the kernel for the filesystem named by fsname and places it into creation mode.

name: fsconfig
description: Configure new or existing filesystem context
signature: int fsconfig(int fd, unsigned int cmd, const char *_key, const void *_value, int aux)
returnDescription: On success, fsconfig () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The fsconfig () system call is part of the suite of file- descriptor-based mount facilities in Linux. fsconfig () is used to supply parameters to and issue commands against the filesystem configuration context associated with the file descriptor fd .

name: fsmount
description: Instantiate mount object from filesystem context
signature: int fsmount(int fs_fd, unsigned int flags, unsigned int attr_flags)
returnDescription: On success, a new file descriptor is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The fsmount () system call is part of the suite of file-descriptor- based mount facilities in Linux. fsmount () creates a new detached mount object for the root of the new filesystem instance referenced by the filesystem context file descriptor fsfd .

name: fspick
signature: int fspick(int dfd, const char *path, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, a new file descriptor is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
