notes: The fspick () system call is part of the suite of file-descriptor- based mount facilities in Linux. fspick () creates a new filesystem configuration context for the extant filesystem instance associated with the path described by dirfd and path , places it into reconfiguration mode (similar to mo...

name: pidfd_open
description: Obtain a file descriptor that refers to a task
signature: int pidfd_open(pid_t pid, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, pidfd_open () returns a file descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The pidfd_open () system call creates a file descriptor that refers to the task referenced by pid . The file descriptor is returned as the function result; the close-on-exec flag is set on the file descriptor.

name: clone3
signature: pid_t clone3(struct clone_args *uargs, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, the thread ID of the child process is returned in the caller's thread of execution.
notes: These system calls create a new ("child") process, in a manner similar to fork(2) . By contrast with fork(2) , these system calls provide more precise control over what pieces of execution context are shared between the calling process and the child process.

name: close_range
description: Close all file descriptors in a given range
signature: int close_range(unsigned int fd, unsigned int max_fd, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, close_range () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The close_range () system call closes all open file descriptors from first to last (included). Errors closing a given file descriptor are currently ignored. flags is a bit mask containing 0 or more of the following: CLOSE_RANGE_CLOEXEC (since Linux 5.

name: openat2
description: Open and possibly create a file (extended)
signature: int openat2(int dfd, const char *filename, struct open_how *how, size_t usize)
returnDescription: On success, a new file descriptor is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The openat2 () system call is an extension of openat(2) and provides a superset of its functionality. The openat2 () system call opens the file specified by path . If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally (if O_CREAT is specified in how.flags ) be created.

name: pidfd_getfd
description: Obtain a duplicate of another process's file descriptor
signature: int pidfd_getfd(int pidfd, int fd, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, pidfd_getfd () returns a file descriptor (a nonnegative integer). On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The pidfd_getfd () system call allocates a new file descriptor in the calling process. This new file descriptor is a duplicate of an existing file descriptor, targetfd , in the process referred to by the PID file descriptor pidfd .

name: faccessat2
description: Check user's permissions for a file
signature: int faccessat2(int dfd, const char *filename, int mode, int flags)
returnDescription: On success (all requested permissions granted, or mode is F_OK and the file exists), zero is returned.
notes: access () checks whether the calling process can access the file path . If path is a symbolic link, it is dereferenced. The mode specifies the accessibility check(s) to be performed, and is either the value F_OK , or a mask consisting of the bitwise OR of one or more of R_OK , W_OK , and X_OK .

name: process_madvise
description: Give advice about use of memory to a process
signature: int process_madvise(int pidfd, const struct iovec *vec, size_t vlen, int behavior, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, process_madvise () returns the number of bytes advised.
notes: The process_madvise () system call is used to give advice or directions to the kernel about the address ranges of another process or of the calling process. It provides the advice for the address ranges described by iovec and n .

name: epoll_pwait2
description: Wait for an I/O event on an epoll file descriptor
signature: int epoll_pwait2(int epfd, struct epoll_event *events, int maxevents, const struct timespec *timeout, const sigset_t *sigmask, size_t sigsetsize)
returnDescription: On success, epoll_wait () returns the number of file descriptors ready for the requested I/O operation, or zero if no file descriptor became ready during the requested timeout milliseconds.
notes: The epoll_wait () system call waits for events on the epoll(7) instance referred to by the file descriptor epfd . The buffer pointed to by events is used to return information from the ready list about file descriptors in the interest list that have some events available.

name: mount_setattr
description: Change properties of a mount or mount tree
signature: int mount_setattr(int dfd, const char *path, unsigned int flags, struct mount_attr *uattr, size_t usize)
returnDescription: On success, mount_setattr () returns zero. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The mount_setattr () system call is part of the suite of file- descriptor-based mount facilities in Linux. mount_setattr () changes the mount properties of a mount or an entire mount tree.

name: quotactl_fd
signature: int quotactl_fd(unsigned int fd, unsigned int cmd, qid_t id, void *addr)
returnDescription: On success, quotactl () returns 0; on error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The quota system can be used to set per-user, per-group, and per- project limits on the amount of disk space used on a filesystem. For each user and/or group, a soft limit and a hard limit can be set for each filesystem. The hard limit can't be exceeded.

name: landlock_create_ruleset
signature: int landlock_create_ruleset(const struct landlock_ruleset_attr *const attr, const size_t size, const __u32 flags)
returnDescription: On success, landlock_create_ruleset () returns a new Landlock ruleset file descriptor, or a Landlock ABI version, according to flags . On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: A Landlock ruleset identifies a set of rules (i.e., actions on objects). This landlock_create_ruleset () system call creates a new file descriptor which identifies a ruleset. This file descriptor can then be used by landlock_add_rule(2) and landlock_restrict_self(2) .

name: landlock_add_rule
description: Add a new Landlock rule to a ruleset
signature: int landlock_add_rule(const int ruleset_fd, const enum landlock_rule_type rule_type, const void *const rule_attr, const __u32 flags)
returnDescription: On success, landlock_add_rule () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: A Landlock rule describes an action on an object which the process intends to perform. A set of rules is aggregated in a ruleset, which can then restrict the thread enforcing it, and its future children. The landlock_add_rule () system call adds a new Landlock rule to an existing ruleset.

name: landlock_restrict_self
signature: int landlock_restrict_self(const int ruleset_fd, const __u32 flags)
returnDescription: On success, landlock_restrict_self () returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: Once a Landlock ruleset is populated with the desired rules, the landlock_restrict_self () system call enforces this ruleset on the calling thread. See landlock(7) for a global overview.

name: memfd_secret
description: Create an anonymous RAM-based file to access secret memory regions
signature: int memfd_secret(unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, memfd_secret () returns a new file descriptor. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: memfd_secret () creates an anonymous RAM-based file and returns a file descriptor that refers to it. The file provides a way to create and access memory regions with stronger protection than usual RAM-based files and anonymous memory mappings.

name: process_mrelease
signature: int process_mrelease(int pidfd, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: futex_waitv
signature: int futex_waitv(struct futex_waitv *waiters, unsigned int nr_futexes, unsigned int flags, struct timespec *timeout, clockid_t clockid)
returnDescription: On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The return value on success depends on the operation.
notes: The futex () system call provides a method for waiting until a certain condition becomes true. It is typically used as a blocking construct in the context of shared-memory synchronization. When using futexes, the majority of the synchronization operations are performed in user space.

name: set_mempolicy_home_node
signature: int set_mempolicy_home_node(unsigned long start, unsigned long len, unsigned long home_node, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: cachestat
description: Query the page cache statistics of a file
signature: int cachestat(unsigned int fd, struct cachestat_range *cstat_range, struct cachestat *cstat, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, cachestat() returns 0. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: cachestat() queries the number of cached pages, dirty pages, pages marked for writeback, evicted pages, and recently evicted pages in the byte range specified by .off and .len in the cachestat_range structure. An evicted page is one that was previously in the page cache but has since been evicted.

name: fchmodat2
signature: int fchmodat2(int dfd, const char *filename, umode_t mode, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The chmod () and fchmod () system calls change a file's mode bits. (The file mode consists of the file permission bits plus the set- user-ID, set-group-ID, and sticky bits.

name: map_shadow_stack
signature: int map_shadow_stack(unsigned long addr, unsigned long size, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: futex_wake
signature: int futex_wake(void *uaddr, unsigned long mask, int nr, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The return value on success depends on the operation.
notes: The futex () system call provides a method for waiting until a certain condition becomes true. It is typically used as a blocking construct in the context of shared-memory synchronization. When using futexes, the majority of the synchronization operations are performed in user space.

name: futex_wait
signature: int futex_wait(void *uaddr, unsigned long val, unsigned long mask, unsigned int flags, struct timespec *timeout, clockid_t clockid)
returnDescription: On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The return value on success depends on the operation.
notes: The futex () system call provides a method for waiting until a certain condition becomes true. It is typically used as a blocking construct in the context of shared-memory synchronization. When using futexes, the majority of the synchronization operations are performed in user space.

name: futex_requeue
signature: int futex_requeue(struct futex_waitv *waiters, unsigned int flags, int nr_wake, int nr_requeue)
returnDescription: On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. The return value on success depends on the operation.
notes: The futex () system call provides a method for waiting until a certain condition becomes true. It is typically used as a blocking construct in the context of shared-memory synchronization. When using futexes, the majority of the synchronization operations are performed in user space.

name: statmount
signature: int statmount(const struct mnt_id_req *req, struct statmount *buf, size_t bufsize, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: To access a mount's status, the caller must have CAP_SYS_ADMIN in the user namespace. This function returns information about a mount, storing it in the buffer pointed to by smbuf . The returned buffer is a struct statmount which is of size bufsize with the fields filled in as described below.

name: listmount
description: Get a list of mount ID's
signature: int listmount(const struct mnt_id_req *req, uint64_t *mnt_ids, size_t nr_mnt_ids, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, the number of entries filled into mnt_ids is returned; 0 if there are no more mounts left. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: To access the mounts in your namespace, you must have CAP_SYS_ADMIN in the user namespace. This function returns a list of mount IDs under the req.mnt_id . This is meant to be used in conjuction with statmount(2) in order to provide a way to iterate and discover mounted file systems.

name: lsm_get_self_attr
signature: int lsm_get_self_attr(unsigned int attr, struct lsm_ctx *ctx, uint32_t *size, uint32_t flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: lsm_set_self_attr
signature: int lsm_set_self_attr(unsigned int attr, struct lsm_ctx *ctx, uint32_t size, uint32_t flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: lsm_list_modules
signature: int lsm_list_modules(uint64_t *ids, uint32_t *size, uint32_t flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: mseal
signature: int mseal(unsigned long start, size_t len, unsigned long flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: setxattrat
signature: int setxattrat(int dfd, const char *pathname, unsigned int at_flags, const char *name, const struct xattr_args *uargs, size_t usize)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: getxattrat
signature: int getxattrat(int dfd, const char *pathname, unsigned int at_flags, const char *name, struct xattr_args *uargs, size_t usize)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: listxattrat
signature: int listxattrat(int dfd, const char *pathname, unsigned int at_flags, char *list, size_t size)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: removexattrat
signature: int removexattrat(int dfd, const char *pathname, unsigned int at_flags, const char *name)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: open_tree_attr
description: Open path or create detached mount object and attach to fd
signature: int open_tree_attr(int dfd, const char *filename, unsigned flags, struct mount_attr *uattr, size_t usize)
returnDescription: On success, a new file descriptor is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The open_tree () system call is part of the suite of file- descriptor-based mount facilities in Linux. â¢ If flags contains OPEN_TREE_CLONE , open_tree () creates a detached mount object which consists of a bind-mount of the path specified by the path .

name: file_getattr
signature: int file_getattr(int dfd, const char *filename, struct file_attr *ufattr, size_t usize, unsigned int at_flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: file_setattr
signature: int file_setattr(int dfd, const char *filename, struct file_attr *ufattr, size_t usize, unsigned int at_flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: cacheflush
description: Flush contents of instruction and/or data cache
signature: int cacheflush(unsigned long addr, unsigned long bytes, unsigned int cache)
returnDescription: cacheflush () returns 0 on success. On error, it returns -1 and sets errno to indicate the error.
notes: cacheflush () flushes the contents of the indicated cache(s) for the user addresses in the range addr to (addr+nbytes-1) . cache may be one of: ICACHE Flush the instruction cache. DCACHE Write back to memory and invalidate the affected valid cache lines. BCACHE Same as (ICACHE|DCACHE) .

name: fstat
signature: int fstat(unsigned int fd, struct __old_kernel_stat *statbuf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These functions return information about a file, in the buffer pointed to by statbuf . No permissions are required on the file itself, butâin the case of stat (), fstatat (), and lstat ()âexecute (search) permission is required on all of the directories in path that lead to the file.

name: fstatfs64
signature: int fstatfs64(unsigned int fd, compat_size_t sz, struct compat_statfs64 *buf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The statfs () system call returns information about a mounted filesystem. path is the pathname of any file within the mounted filesystem.

name: lstat
signature: int lstat(const char *filename, struct __old_kernel_stat *statbuf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These functions return information about a file, in the buffer pointed to by statbuf . No permissions are required on the file itself, butâin the case of stat (), fstatat (), and lstat ()âexecute (search) permission is required on all of the directories in path that lead to the file.

name: mmap_pgoff
description: Map or unmap files or devices into memory
signature: int mmap_pgoff(unsigned long addr, unsigned long len, unsigned long prot, unsigned long flags, unsigned long fd, unsigned long pgoff)
returnDescription: On success, mmap () returns a pointer to the mapped area. On error, the value MAP_FAILED (that is, (void *) -1 ) is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. On success, munmap () returns 0.
notes: mmap () creates a new mapping in the virtual address space of the calling process. The starting address for the new mapping is specified in addr . The length argument specifies the length of the mapping (which must be greater than 0).

name: nice
signature: int nice(int increment)
returnDescription: On success, the new nice value is returned (but see VERSIONS below). On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error. A successful call can legitimately return -1.
notes: nice () adds inc to the nice value for the calling thread. (A higher nice value means a lower priority.) The range of the nice value is +19 (low priority) to -20 (high priority). Attempts to set a nice value outside the range are clamped to the range.

name: recv
description: Receive a message from a socket
signature: int recv(int fd, void *buf, compat_size_t len, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: These calls return the number of bytes received, or -1 if an error occurred. In the event of an error, errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The recv (), recvfrom (), and recvmsg () calls are used to receive messages from a socket. They may be used to receive data on both connectionless and connection-oriented sockets.

name: riscv_flush_icache
signature: int riscv_flush_icache(uintptr_t start, uintptr_t end, uintptr_t flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.
notes: __riscv_flush_icache () enforces ordering between stores and instruction cache fetches. The range of addresses over which ordering is enforced is specified by start and end .

name: riscv_hwprobe
signature: int riscv_hwprobe(struct riscv_hwprobe *pairs, size_t pair_count, size_t cpusetsize, unsigned long *cpus, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, returns 0. On error, -1 is returned and errno is set.

name: send
description: Send a message on a socket
signature: int send(int fd, void *buff, size_t len, unsigned int flags)
returnDescription: On success, these calls return the number of bytes sent. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The system calls send (), sendto (), and sendmsg () are used to transmit a message to another socket. The send () call may be used only when the socket is in a connected state (so that the intended recipient is known). The only difference between send () and write(2) is the presence of flags .

name: sendfile
signature: ssize_t sendfile(int out_fd, int in_fd, compat_off_t *offset, compat_size_t count)
returnDescription: If the transfer was successful, the number of bytes written to out_fd is returned.
notes: sendfile () copies data between one file descriptor and another. Because this copying is done within the kernel, sendfile () is more efficient than the combination of read(2) and write(2) , which would require transferring data to and from user space.

name: stat
signature: int stat(const char *filename, struct __old_kernel_stat *statbuf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: These functions return information about a file, in the buffer pointed to by statbuf . No permissions are required on the file itself, butâin the case of stat (), fstatat (), and lstat ()âexecute (search) permission is required on all of the directories in path that lead to the file.

name: statfs64
signature: int statfs64(const char *pathname, compat_size_t sz, struct compat_statfs64 *buf)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: The statfs () system call returns information about a mounted filesystem. path is the pathname of any file within the mounted filesystem.

name: uname
description: Get name and information about current kernel
signature: int uname(struct old_utsname *name)
returnDescription: On success, zero is returned. On error, -1 is returned, and errno is set to indicate the error.
notes: uname () returns system information in the structure pointed to by buf . The utsname struct is defined in <sys/utsname.h> : struct utsname { char sysname[]; /* Operating system name (e.g.

name: waitpid
description: Wait for process to change state
signature: pid_t waitpid(pid_t pid, int *stat_addr, int options)
returnDescription: wait (): on success, returns the process ID of the terminated child; on failure, -1 is returned.
notes: All of these system calls are used to wait for state changes in a child of the calling process, and obtain information about the child whose state has changed. A state change is considered to be: the child terminated; the child was stopped by a signal; or the child was resumed by a signal.
